./.title: Introduction
./.body:
Cabify backend bootcamp
Introduction
Welcome!
This book is intended to bridge the gap between what you learned in a Web development bootcamp and what it takes to build and operate backends for real-world products.
You already know how to build a backend for a Web application: you write some code, you put it in a server somewhere, you configure some database, and you hit 'run'. Simple enough, no? 
But, when you join a medium-sized project, you'll find that, typically, things are not so simple. We set out to protect ourselves from all kinds of failure scenarios by ensuring our backends don't just work, but are robust.
For example, have you ever considered what happens to your backend...

... when you have 10x, 100x, 1000x more requests to your server?
... when the database disk catches fire?
... when the datacenter hosting your server has an outage?

To address these kind of failures, and others more mundane but also more subtle, backends tend to get complicated: lots of middle layers, lots of different tools everywhere, architecture diagrams with lots of boxes and arrows, strange artifacts in the code, intricate procedures to do things that, for simple systems, would be a couple of commands away.
This complexity can be overwhelming at first. It's not obvious to understand what's the purpose of everything, how it all fits together, why things are done that particular way, and which are the implications. So that this transition is easier, and you can become a productive, knowledgeable contributor to the team as soon as possible, we'll learn all this from the ground up.
We won't teach you about specific technologies. Depending on the team you end up joining, you will find different langugages, databases, deployment systems, all kinds of different buzzwords that will sound alien to you. You can teach yourself those comparatively easily, if needed.
Rather, we'll focus on the commonalities: the building principles for which all those technologies are nothing but implementations. Tools come and go, but principles remain. Plus, tools cannot shield you from those principles: some are fundamental in nature, and permeate every single component of a production-grade Web architecture.
We'll go through the theory, and then apply it to a real project.
Requirements
Basic knowledge of JavaScript, Node.js, Express.js, MongoDB, and the command line interface is assumed.

001-programming-a-backend/.title: Programming a backend
001-programming-a-backend/.body:
Programming a backend
Backends are fundamentally different to programs that you run in your own computer. Let's explore why, and what to do about it.

001-programming-a-backend/01-more-than-o.title: More than one computer
001-programming-a-backend/01-more-than-o.body:
More than one computer
Frontend + Backend = Distributed system
This bootcamp is about backends. The word backend implies being part of a bigger system that has, at least, a frontend counterpart of some kind.
Frontends and backends run on different computers. Frontends run on user's devices, such as laptops, mobile phones, or even lightbulbs nowadays.
Frontends and backends need to talk to each other. Since they run on different computers, they need to do so over a network.
A system comprised of computers that talk to each other over a network is called a distributed system.

Computers send messages to each other over a medium that loses them
If you get nothing else from this bootcamp, let it be this:

Computers send messages to each other over a medium that loses them.

Everything we'll learn in this course is just different ways this fact affects building systems that do their job.

The medium loses messages
The physical link between two computers can break. Someone might trip over the wire. If it's a wireless network, one of them might go into a tunnel. The Internet, composed of millions and millions of links like these, can break in unquantifiable ways.
A consequence of this is that:

When you send a message, you don't know whether it will reach its destination.

But what if it's important to know that the message reached the other end? After all, you're trying to get computers to collaborate!
You might suggest: let's agree with the recipient for them to reply back with another message telling us that they have received the message.
But, in exactly the same fashion, since this message goes through the same unreliable medium, it can be lost too! So we reach another necessary consequence:

When you don't get the response you're expecting, you have no idea if the recipient received your message in the first place.

A knee-jerk reaction to not getting such a response is to assume that the whole communication failed, that is, that it was your message to the recipient that was lost, not their reply back to you. This assumption doesn't always work! Think about a monetary transaction: if you tell another computer to move some money, and it doesn't reply back, you can't just assume that it didn't move the money.

sequenceDiagram
  participant C as Client
  participant S as Server

  C ->>+ S: "Transfer 100$ to Alice"

  note left of S: There's some delay processing the request.

  C ->> C: ðŸš¨ Timeout ðŸš¨

  note left of S: Retrying...

  C ->>+ S: "Transfer 100$ to Alice"

  S ->>- C: OK
  S ->>- C: OK

  note over C: (Where's my money?)


Your solutions must take these two realities into account in order to work robustly. How? Well, keep reading!
You don't know how long it will take a message to reach the other side
When you are a computer and you're expecting a message, you have two choices:

Wait indefinitely.
Give up after some time.

Wait indefinitely
If you wait indefinitely, the task you're going to do on receiving the message will be delayed indefinitely. This may mean leaving a user waiting, staring at a spinner, until they give up and close your app, this time really forever. If it's not a person who's waiting, but an automatic process of some kind, you might leave that waiting forever.
This is rarely the optimal solution.
Give up after some time
This is what we call a timeout.
It works like this: you set a timer alongside an operation that you don't know how long will take. In our case, waiting for a message from another computer.
If the operation finishes first, then the timer is canceled and everything works. You have successfully coordinated through an ocean of uncertainty, hooray!

sequenceDiagram
  participant C as Client
  participant S as Server

  C ->> C: Set timer
  C ->>+ S: "Do this"
  S ->>- C: OK
  C ->> C: Cancel timer


But if the timer finishes first, you cancel the operation (this cancellation might take several forms), acknowledge that the communication failed, and handle the situation as best as you can. We'll see how.

sequenceDiagram
  participant C as Client
  participant S as Server

  C ->> C: Set timer
  C ->>+ S: "Do this"

  note left of S: The request has some delay

  C ->> C: ðŸš¨ Timeout ðŸš¨

  C ->> C: Mark operation as failed



Caution: timeouts tell you nothing
Remember:

When you don't get the response you're expecting, you don't know if the recipient received your message in the first place.

To which we may add:

When you haven't received the response you're expecting yet, you don't know whether you will receive it or not in the future.

So, on a timeout, there are four possibilities. You haven't received the response yet because...

... your message got lost and never reached nor will it ever reach the recipient, so they can't reply back.


sequenceDiagram
  participant F as Server A
  participant N as Network (abstract)
  participant B as Server B

  F ->> N: "Do this"

  note right of N: (Some routing failure occurs and message is lost.)

  F ->> F: ðŸš¨ Timeout ðŸš¨



... your message didn't reach its recipient yet, but it might in the future, so it might reply back eventually.


sequenceDiagram
  participant F as Server A
  participant N as Network (abstract)
  participant B as Server B

  F ->> N: "Do this"

  note right of N: (There's some delay due to network latency.)

  F ->> F: ðŸš¨ Timeout ðŸš¨

  N ->>+ B: "Do this"
  B ->>- N: OK
  N ->> F: OK




... your message reached the recipient, but the response got lost and you will never receive it.


sequenceDiagram
  participant F as Server A
  participant N as Network (abstract)
  participant B as Server B

  F ->> N: "Do this"
  N ->>+ B: "Do this"

  note left of N: (Some routing failure occurs and message is lost.)

  B ->>- N: OK
  F ->> F: ðŸš¨ Timeout ðŸš¨



... your message reached the recipient; the response hasn't reached you yet, but it might in the future.


sequenceDiagram
  participant F as Server A
  participant N as Network (abstract)
  participant B as Server B

  F ->> N: "Do this"
  N ->>+ B: "Do this"
  B ->>- N: OK

  note left of N: (There's some delay due to network latency.)

  F ->> F: ðŸš¨ Timeout ðŸš¨
  N ->> F: OK


A very common pitfall is to assume that, since the communication failed, it never reached and it won't ever reach the recipient and so it won't have any effect. This is only true in scenario 1 out of the four.
For example: say your backend calls a database to store something. It expects the database to reply back, either confirming the operation or reporting some kind of error (maybe you didn't have permissions or something). But the call times out instead. In this case, you can't tell whether a later read to the database will retrieve the data you intended to store or not.
You should only behave as if you know that the operation has failed (or succeeded) at the other end if doing so is a reasonable assumption for your use case. But you have to plan for the consequences. We'll look more into this.
Another, more subtle, pitfall is to assume that, because you have timed out, the message has either reached the recipient (scenarios 3 and 4) or will never reach it (scenario 1). But, in scenario 2, your message could eventually arrive and have an effect at some point in the future! This is especially relevant when retrying the operation; keep reading.
Keep calm and embrace uncertainty
Let's start with some good news: most of the time, things just work, especially for simple systems that don't have a lot of load and don't depend on a lot of communication; and, most of the time, a simplistic communication failure handling that just assumes the whole operation failed and aborts gives good enough results.
This is because most operations aren't critical and it's safe if the user just retries them if they want.
For example, when changing the Twitter bio, it's OK if the user is told "sorry, the operation failed, try again after a while" even if it actually succeeded or will eventually succeed. The user will just click "Save" again and save the same thing, or, if they don't, maybe they'll just be surprised later if the aborted bio shows up. No big deal.
But think about monetary transactions and things get ugly fast!
In Cabify, when a journey is finished, the driver sends a "drop-off" message to our backend and our backend charges the rider some amount. What if this message times out?
We can't just abort the drop-off and leave the journey hanging. Also, we can't just assume that the drop-off reached the backend and it's just that its response got lost or delayed. We just don't know if the operation has succeeded and the rider has been charged or if it has failed and the rider hasn't been charged. So what can we do?
It's not enough to just resend the drop-off, like in the simplistic strategy above. If the previous message did get to its recipient, then the rider was charged and when the new drop-off arrives, the rider will be charged again!
Continued retries + idempotency = guaranteed eventual success
What we're missing is idempotency. Idempotency means that processing the same message any number of times yields the same effects as processing it just once.
Idempotency allows us to retry communicating any number of times without worry. If you don't get confirmation that a message has succeeded, just retry it! If it didn't succeed previously, maybe it will now. If it did succeed previously, then the new attempt will just be ignored.

By retrying an idempotent operation until you see it succeed, you know it will be performed exactly once.

There are different ways to achieve idempotency. The simplest is to keep track on the backend of which messages you have already processed. When you get a message, you first check if you've already processed it. If you have, then you do nothing.
In our example, when our backend processes a drop-off, we internally mark the journey as finished. If we receive the drop-off again, we first check that the journey hasn't already finished. If it has, then we just do nothing so the rider won't get charged twice.
Caution: communication success != operation success
It's a common pitfall to mix the operation itself with the communication of the operation.
If you ask someone to do something and they respond "no I won't," then the operation failed (you didn't get what you wanted) but the communication succeeded (they heard your request and you heard their response).
If you do the same over the phone and as soon as you have finished asking you enter a tunnel and lose connectivity meaning you never hear the response back, then the communication failed and the operation may or may not have succeeded (they may have said "OK," hung up and left).
Your natural reaction to this situation would be to call back and ask the same thing:

If they didn't hear you before you entered the tunnel, then they'll either respond "OK" or "no I won't." By retrying, you have made sure that the communication has finally succeeded! If you kept accidentally entering tunnels at the worst possible times, then you would just keep calling and eventually you would get the message through, even at the cost of exasperating whoever's on the other side. (In time, we'll see how an exasperated server looks like).

If they did hear you before, they'll typically respond either "again, I won't" or "I have already performed the operation." This is idempotency at play! Only very obtuse people would happily do the same thing again. Idempotency is just common sense to us; sadly, common sense needs to be taught to the machines. This allows us to repeat communications without fear that we will trigger the consequences too many times.


The point is that distinguishing communication failure from operation failure comes naturally to us but not so much to our distributed programs, so we need to be aware of this distinction.
Communication failures are typically called transport layer failures. Operation failures are called application layer failures.
This mix up is made worse by our programming languages and libraries, which often report both communication failure and operation failure in a single err variable. Letâ€™s look at an example API client request for retrieving an artist from the Spotify API:
spotify.getArtist('Rosalia')
  .catch(function onError(err) {
    console.log(err);
  });

In the probable case an error happens, how best to deal with it? One way to deal with these exceptions would be to handle each http status in a different way:
spotify.getArtist('Rosalia')
  .catch(function onError(err) {
    if (err.status === 400) {
      console.log('Bad request, Rosalia does not exist.');
    } else if (err.status === 401) {
      console.log('No valid API key provided.');
    } else if (err.status === 404) {
      console.log('The requested resource does not exist.');
    }
  });

However, this way of handling the error assumes the error comes from an operational issue when the truth can be much more damning. For example, what happens if the error is in fact due to a timeout in the network request? There's no status code in there...
This may be the main reason why this is such a common pitfall, combined with the fact that, as we said before in our Twitter bio example, just equating communication failure with operation failure works in many cases.
Guaranteed eventual success + ordering preservation = guaranteed eventual agreement
There's still one potential problem, though.
Imagine you send a message to your backend like "set Twitter bio to 'I ate cockroaches'". This times out: it's stuck in the network somewhere, being delayed, so it hasn't made it to the backend. You retry the operation after a while, and now it succeeds.
Now you realize the bio has a typo and send another message: "set Twitter bio to 'I hate cockroaches'". It succeeds.
But the first message is still out there, in the network. Say it eventually gets through to the backend. If the backend happily processes it, the bio will now read "I ate cockroaches", while you still think it reads "I hate cockroaches".
This is just one way, a subtle one, that messages can be processed in a different order than they're sent. Systems are rarely designed for it. Many naively assume a series of request-response communications necessarily result in client and server agreeing on the end result. Well, now you know better!
Another way out-of-order processing may happen is a very common frontend pitfall: sending concurrent (meaning: overlapping in time) AJAX requests that the user thinks are serial (meaning: not concurrent; one fully after another).
For example: the user writes "I ate cockroaches" and clicks "Save", and you send an AJAX request to the backend. Now the user realizes the typo, writes "I hate cockroaches" and hits "Save" again. You immediately send an AJAX request again, even if the first one hasn't finished yet.

sequenceDiagram
  participant F as Frontend
  participant N as Network (abstract)
  participant B as Backend

  F ->> N: set bio: "I ate cockroaches"

  note right of N: (Some time passes.)

  F ->> N: set bio: "I hate cockroaches"
  N ->>+ B: set bio: "He hates cockroaches"
  B -->>- N: OK
  N -->> F: OK

  note right of N: (First message finally gets delivered.)

  N ->>+ B: set bio: "He ate cockroaches"
  B -->>- N: Weird but OK
  N -->> F: OK


Now, the previous request might not even have reached the backend yet. In fact, the next one may take a different path and reach the backend first. So the backend first processes "set Twitter bio to 'I hate cockroaches'", and, once the first request arrives, it processes "set Twitter bio to 'I ate cockroaches'". The user thinks they fixed the typo, but, from the backend's perspective, they introduced it later!
This situation can be fixed by telling the backend the order in which messages are supposed to be processed. There are several ways to do this; instead of "do this" and "do that", messages might take the form "1. do this" and "2. do that", or "do this, as a first action" and "do that, after action 'do this'". The backend can then detect messages received out of order, and act consequently.
With ordering preservation in place, we have the whole receipt for eventual agreement:

If you do a series of idempotent operations, retry each of them until you see them succeed, and the backend preserves the order in which you sent them, then the backend and you agree on exactly which operations have been performed by you.

This is a powerful guarantee that we'll explore in depth in the "Distributed data" section.
TCP has your back, except not really
In fact, communications do this all the time behind our backs. Most of the Internet runs on a protocol called TCP that has retries, idempotency, and ordering preservation built in.
But TCP can't fully save you:

You rarely send all your communications between two computers through a single TCP connection. For example, in the "set Twitter bio" AJAX example before, each AJAX operation is a HTTP request, which browsers will typically send in different TCP connections.

Even if you do, TCP is a transport layer protocol: it just copies chunks of data from one computer to another and calls it a day. But operations are more than just meaningless data: they're application level, things that are processed and have consequences. You typically require confirmation by the backend that things were processed, because just receiving well-formed messages (what TCP guarantees) is only the beginning of the backend's job. So, just like TCP guarantees both ends eventually agree on which chunks of data were transferred, you need to guarantee your frontend and your backend agree on which operations were performed (if you want!).


If you send message "42. pay 1000 USD to Alice" twice over the same TCP connection, TCP will happily ensure your backend receives something like:
request arrived: '"42. pay 1000 USD to Alice"';
request arrived: '"42. pay 1000 USD to Alice"';
instead of an incomprehensible mess of arbitrarily duplicated, reordered, and missing chunks of data, like:
ved: '"42. pay 10request arrirequest arri00 USD to Alicrequest are"';
Alice"';
Alice"';
request arrived:
But it's up to your backend to ensure that you don't do operation 42 twice!

001-programming-a-backend/02-serving-an-.title: Serving an API
001-programming-a-backend/02-serving-an-.body:
Serving an API
Services are served by servers to clients
Computers talk to each other in all sorts of ways. For programming backends, we're not that interested in many of them; for example, we're not going to look into peer-to-peer communication models, such as BitTorrent or Bitcoin. (Although both are technically fascinating!)
The communication model that is most used between frontends and backends, and between different parts of backends, is the client-server model.
In the client-server model, there's some kind of service being, well, served. Then, there are two roles for participating computers:

Computers that use the service, called clients.
Those that serve the service, called servers.

We'll explore the relationship between clients and servers in detail in this chapter.
Protocols: the language in which computers talk
Clients and servers must share a common understanding on how to communicate: a protocol.
In practice, a protocol is really a composition of protocols from different layers. On low-level layers, computers agree on the basics about how to communicate. By using standard protocols for those layers, you can get advantage of existing tools that know about those protocols, such as routers, operating systems and web browser, and focus on what makes your use case different.
There are protocols that:

Work out the details of how to find a computer in the network: IP, DNS.
Just move data between computers: TCP (reliable, but heavyweight), UDP (not reliable, but lightweight).
Encrypt the data, to avoid tampering and ensure privacy: TLS.
Describe ways of shaping this data into messages, and how messages are sequenced: HTTP, JSON-RPC, gRPC, WebSockets.

Ways of serving
Different protocols implement different patterns of communication between clients and servers. Let's explore some of those.
Requests get responses
The most common way of serving services is by accepting messages from clients, called requests, that specify what they want the service to do for them; and, after some work is done, sending a message back to the client, called a response, with some kind of feedback about the request.

sequenceDiagram
  client ->>+ server: make me a sandwich
  activate client
  note right of server: *mumble* *rumble*
  server ->>- client: ðŸ¥ª
  deactivate client


This is, for instance, how HTTP works. Each time you visit a web page, you're being a client of a service; the browser sends a HTTP request to the servers, that respond with content.
Don't push to me, I'll pull from you
When you go to the hospital, you don't just immediately go into the doctor's office, sit down and start telling them your pains and sorrows right away, without even minding if there's already some other patient in there. Instead, you wait in a room for the doctor to call you when they're ready to serve your request.
This is pull-based serving, as opposed to push-based. It's mostly used when, rather than expecting a meaningful response from the server, the client provides the data to the server, without being really interested in a response from it.
Here, the request is sent from the server to the client, and the client responds to it.

sequenceDiagram
  participant client
  participant server
  server ->> client: need your data
  client ->> server: have all this data, enjoy


The advantage of pulling data instead of waiting for it to be pushed is that the server decides when to pull it, which can be more efficient, since the server knows better than the client when it's preferable to have the data.
Streams of responses
Sometimes, instead of expecting a response to a request as soon as possible, clients expect a series of responses, being sent whenever they are ready. Think something like chat: as people post messages, they're delivered to you.

sequenceDiagram
  client ->>+ server: connect to chat
  activate client
  server ->> client: OK, hang on for messages

  note right of server: (Some time passes.)

  Alice ->>+ server: hi!
  activate Alice
  server ->>- Alice: OK
  deactivate Alice

  server ->> client: Alice says: hi!

  note right of server: (Some time passes.)

  Bob ->>+ server: I'm here too!
  activate Bob

  Alice ->>+ server: how are you?
  activate Alice

  server ->>- Alice: OK
  deactivate Alice

  server ->> client: Alice says: how are you?

  server ->>- Bob: OK
  deactivate Bob

  server ->> client: Bob says: I'm here too!

  deactivate client


This is useful when the client wants to be notified when events happen as soon as possible after they happen.
A downside is that both client and server need to keep the stream open, which, as we'll extensively see, consumes system resources.
Web protocols that enable streams: SSE, WebSocket.
Long polling
You can trick a request-response protocol into behaving like a stream. The trick is to send a request and, instead of expecting a response right away, let the server respond only once a new event arrives. Once you get the response, you send the request again.

sequenceDiagram
  client ->>+ server: get me messages
  activate client

  note right of server: (Some time passes.)

  Alice ->>+ server: hi!
  activate Alice
  server ->>- Alice: OK
  deactivate Alice

  server ->>- client: Alice says: hi!
  deactivate client
  client ->>+ server: get me messages
  activate client

  note right of server: (Some time passes.)

  Bob ->>+ server: I'm here too!
  activate Bob

  Alice ->>+ server: how are you?
  activate Alice

  server ->>- Alice: OK
  deactivate Alice

  server ->>- client: Alice says: how are you?
  deactivate client

  server ->>- Bob: OK
  deactivate Bob

  client ->>+ server: get me messages
  activate client
  server ->>- client: Bob says: I'm here too!

  deactivate client


The main advantage of this is that you can use a request-response protocol, such as HTTP, which are more ubiquitous and thus are familiar to more clients developers and have more libraries available for all kinds of platforms.
Stream from A to B + stream from B to A = connection
If, instead of from server to client only, messages are streamed in both directions, we have a connection.
Going back to the chat application, we had:

A stream-based protocol for retrieving messages.
A request-response protocol for posting messages.

It's more efficient to just have a single connection for both. This has basically no resources overhead over plain streams, and spares us the overhead of the request-response protocol.
A connection-based protocol available in Web browsers is WebSockets.
Application Programing Interface
Once you've decided how your server will communicate with its clients, you must choose a stack of standard protocols that best match your needs, and, on top of those, add a protocol that you define. The protocol that is specific to an application is usually called the API.
The API is the external interface that a system exposes to let others build programs on top of it.
It is different from a user interface, which is supposed to be used by a person directly through human-friendly input and output methods: buttons, commands, text, images, etc.
Instead, an API is supposed to be used programmatically, by writing code.
In the case of servers, APIs are exposed to clients through the network, on top of other protocols that deal with communication details.
Even though APIs are for machines to call, it's people the ones writing the code that deals with them. Bad APIs make people miserable and systems brittle. While what constitutes a good API is, as with most aspects of human interaction, fairly subjective, there are a few principles that are a necessary factor in designing good APIs.
An API is a contract
The first and most crucial requirement for a good API is that it is well defined.
APIs get old
Here's a fact of life: you will want to change your API. Here's another: you won't be able to, because there will be clients depending on it.
The code your clients are using to access your old API won't magically change at exactly the same time your server stop serving it. Mobile apps won't get updated, browser tabs won't refresh, services depending on yours won't be deployed until after some time passes, or, in the worst case, never.
Backwards-compatible additions
Instead of changing your API, consider adding things to it.
State very clearly which kind of additions are considered backwards-compatible. A good list would include:

Adding kinds of requests: methods, endpoints, resources, etc.
Adding fields to object types.
Adding parameters to kinds of requests, if the protocol allows it: query parameters in URLs, optional arguments in methods, etc.

Versioning
When breaking changes can't be avoided, it's best to keep running the old API alongside the new one.
Clients should be told that the should update to take advantage of the new, better API.
Programmer-friendliness
In the end, a programmer is the one that needs to understand and adapt to your API. A good API is designed with this in mind.
Being friendly to people is more art than science. It entails things like being simple, powerful, easy to use, flexible, etc. But let's see a few recommendations that are usually programmer-friendly APIs.
Follow conventions
Yours is not the only API programmers have seen or will see in their lives. If your API resembles those they already knew, you can leverage that familiarity in order to reduce friction.
There will probably be libraries, tools, etc. built around those conventions.
Give good error feedback
Use precisely codified errors and informative error messages in your responses to faulty requests.
Keep ceremony to a minimum
Set sane defaults when they make sense. But careful: this is a slippery slope. You might end up doing things by default that are annoying or surprising to many people.
Provide client libraries
Specially when your API is complex, providing a client library may be a good idea.
A client library should not be substitute for a good platform-agnostic API: platforms change, and you might end up inducing more friction.
TCP connections and your API
Ideally, when serving your API, you wouldn't need to care too much about the underlying protocols. Things would just work beneath you.
In practice, when things go wrong, those foundational protocols break and your API is affected. If you want your API to be well-defined, you can't escape from that fact. Effectively, the underlying protocols are part of your API.
In particular, TCP is such a fundamental protocol that is is worth knowing in some detail how it affects your API.
Delivery guarantees
As long as the connection is not broken, TCP ensures that the data you send is received:

Eventually
Only once
In the order it was sent
Incorrupt

Server: cancel work when the connection dies
There are three ways a connection should be declared dead:

You receive a FIN when you expected the other end to keep sending data. In Node.js, this manifests itself as an end event emitted on the net.Socket or a http.Client object.
You receive a RST. This means the other end has declared the connection as broken and tells you to do so too, for whatever reason. This is the "connection reset by peer" error that manifests itself as an error event emitted on the request object.
The connection times out.

You should listen to those events, propagate them, and stop doing things in your request handler as soon as possible.
Client: close the connection if you don't need a response anymore
In the browser's XMLHTTPRequest, call the abort method.
In Node.js's http.ClientRequest, call the destroy method.
RPC
RPC means Remote Procedure Call.
It basically means that you send a request and get a response, similarly to how you would call a procedure (a method or a function) and get a return value in your programming language.
HTTP as a transport
HTTP is a protocol on top of TCP designed to interact with hypertext, that is, Web pages. But, since there's a lot of tooling already in place for HTTP, it's usual to rely on it as a transport layer for RPC.
JSON-RPC
JSON-RPC is a particular way of encoding RPC calls in HTTP, using JSON.
The nice thing about JSON-RPC is that there are tons of libraries available for it, in many platforms.
REST
In REST, you define your API in terms of resources. A resource is something that can be retrieved, maybe modified, and maybe deleted.
CRUD operations:

GET
Reads a resource.
Cacheable.
Must be idempotent.


POST
Writes a resource, or provoke an effect of some kind.
Not necessarily idempotent.
But you need to make it idempotent if you want strong delivery guarantees, to safely support retries.




PUT
Writes a resource by replacing it wholly.
Must be idempotent.


DELETE
Deletes a resource.
Must be idempotent.


PATCH
Replaces just part of a resource. Pretty error-prone; usually not worth it.



This is how browsers work, mostly.
Virtually all platforms have good support for RESTful APIs.
Provides familiar semantics. Or that's the myth. In practice, it's not that well understood, and you'll find yourself shoehorning things into it, since not everything can be expressed in terms of resources.
Because of this, just declaring your API as "RESTful" doesn't mean there's no need to define your API in very precise terms.
REST also requires you to respond with semantically valid status codes:

200-299: Things went well.
400-499: Something went bad, because of the client.
500-599: Something went bad, because of the server.

You can get fancy, or you can stick to:

200 OK
400 Bad Request
401 Unauthorized
403 Forbidden
404 Not Found
500 Internal Server Error
503 Service Unavailable

Deriving code from contracts
Many tools let you derive both client and server code from a common language that specifies part of your contract. This is nice because it enforces that part of the contract in a uniform, robust way, so that you can focus on the other parts.

001-programming-a-backend/03-the-backend.title: The backend's backends
001-programming-a-backend/03-the-backend.body:
The backend's backends
Failures don't end with communication
The picture we've painted so far may look like this: to accomplish some task, computers talk to one another through a dark, misty, treacherous Ocean of Uncertainty in which messages get lost, sink, or are left adrift indefinitely; but, once a lucky message makes it to the other side of this ocean, all trouble is then behind, the recipient does its part of the task with full reliability, and only when it's time to send another message back with a response does the possibility of failure come back again.
If only things were so easy! The truth is, this picture is missing two extra sources of failures:

The recipient may crash at any point while processing a message.
The recipient's part of the task may involve communicating with one or more extra computers, so:
As we know, those communications can fail.
Those computers can also crash.
Those computers may, in turn, communicate with even more computers.



But this should not lead us to pessimism. In fact, distributed systems can be made more reliable than any system running in a single computer can dream of. When you're done with this course, you will have a pretty complete overview of the main techniques to achieve that reliability. You will have attained the ability to create programs with superpowers that outlive any fallible machine that runs them and overcome however many obstacles are put in their way.
So, with that in mind, let's see what we can do about failure in the backend, and in the backend's backends.
Let it crash
Server-side recovery
A common way of thinking when attempting to build robustness into a backend is to recover as much as possible from errors in the backend itself: catch all exceptions, think hard about all possible combinations of failed states and come up with ways to reach a more desirable state from those.
Crashes will happen, anyway
Here's the thing: there's always the possibility of crashes. A machine can just die, for all sorts of reasons. At any point of a backend's execution. If you want your distributed program to actually be reliable, it needs to recover from that scenario. Since backends can die, it follows that you can't rely on the backend to recover from its own failures: it might be too dead to do anything useful. The sophisticated damage control mechanisms you have put in place won't even have a chance to make things right if the program that runs them just halts.
Given this fact of life, you can actually take advantage of it to make your system simpler. Given the other components of the system already have to consider the possibility of your death, whenever you find yourself in a not-so-ideal state, just crash!
Crashing gently
It's worth clarifying what we mean by crash here, as something that your program does as opposed to something that happens to it. It basically means to act as if the computer was suddenly turned off, that is, stop operations immediately. With some caveats:

Limit the crash to the context in which the error happened. If you're handling a request, just abort the request handler, not the whole program!
If someone is waiting for a response from you, try to actively inform them of the crash as soon as possible. You should send a suitable error response, and/or abruptly close the TCP connection, if applies. This allows the other side to recover as soon as possible from your failure.
Report as much debug information as it might be useful. We'll see how in further chapters.

This technique is called let it crash: crashing is nothing to be worried about if someone else, somewhere else is expecting it to happen, so... just let it crash!
As with any other general technique in programming, this one isn't to be applied blindly at every occasion. Sometimes, it can be justified to have some degree of recovery in the backend itself. Handling crashes usually involves some amount of service degradation, and recovering from errors in the backend can reduce it, at the cost of a more complex system with more possible states to consider. Use your judgement to decide if this complexity is justified or not. Just know that it's optional, and it shouldn't affect system-wide robustness if the system is designed right.
Crashes are indistinguishable from failed communications
We've put a lot of faith in someone else, somewhere else to recover from our crashes. That someone, somewhere can just be the computer that is waiting for your response. And, turns out, we've already seen what to do to recover from crashes on the server, from the client's perspective.
The key insight here is that a crash and a failed communication look the same to the client. You wanted a response, be it some result value or just some kind of acknowledgment that the message is processed successfully, and you didn't get it in time. The only difference is that, for efficiency (to reduce waits) and debuggability purposes, you may have received an error response (in the 5xx range, if you're speaking HTTP), a connection broken event, or some other kind of failure signal instead of a timeout.
So you do exactly the same as you would do on a timeout. This reduces the complexity of your distributed recovery mechanism significantly by having a unified strategy that works in all scenarios.
Partial failures
A backend usually acts as a coordinator for other backends. Sometimes, this involves causing several effects that are independent of each other. For example, you might want to send an email and then (or in parallel) save something in a database.
Given that those effects are the result of messages sent in a distributed system, they can fail, as any other distributed operation. And, given they're independent from each other, they can fail independently.
If some operations succeeded while others failed or weren't even attempted, then we have partial failure.
Partial failure is usually trickier to handle than total failure. You typically want either all effects or none of them to take place. On partial failure, the robust thing to do is to try to move the system towards one of those two states, so that things aren't left half-done.
The recovery approach: undo or retry
Let's consider two choices:

Undo the operations that succeeded. This moves the system towards the total failure state.
Retry the operations that failed. This moves the system towards the total success state.

But there are problems with those strategies:

Undoing may not be possible at all. For example, you can't unsend an email.
Retrying may trigger duplicate effects, if the original attempt yielded just a communication failure which didn't correspond to an operational failure: the operation arrived but its acknowledgement got lost, or it will arrive eventually.
Undoing and retrying are distributed operations themselves, and thus can also fail. So we keep retrying them too? For how long?
If the program crashes, the pending undo or retry operations will never happen, unless they're preventively put in a job queue before and then canceled somehow. (We'll see more about queues in time.)

Both are quite complicated solutions that fall into server-side recovery strategy. How can we fit partial failures in a let it crash strategy?
The let it crash approach: idempotency + retry all
Actually, we already know what to do. We know from the first chapter than, in order to be robust, a distributed operation needs to be idempotent, so that it can be retried as many times as necessary to get confirmation that it succeed.
This means that we should be already planning for the possibility that the current operation (that is, the one processed by your backend, which coordinates the independent sub-operations that we're discussing) is retried by the client, even if there's no failure at all in the backend. This means that the operation needs to be made idempotent.
We can take advantage of this when partial failure occurs. We just follow let it crash: we just treat partial failure as total failure and crash the request handling.
This is supposed to trigger a retry from the client. The retry will, in turn, cause the backend to retry its sub-operations, even those that had succeeded before, if there were any.
This retry may fail too, either partially or fully, but that would in turn trigger another retry.
Since those sub-operations are also idempotent, it doesn't matter if they were previously successful or not. If they were successful, then retrying will have no effect. If they had failed in a previous attempt, then maybe this time they will succeed.
Eventually, after enough retries, all sub-operations will have succeeded.
The end-to-end robustness of idempotency + retries
If, at this point, you're still not convinced that idempotency combined with continued retries from the client is the way to go, let us recall what it has bought us so far:

It recovers from messages that get lost, arbitrarily delayed, or duplicated in an unreliable medium.
It recovers from crashes in the server.
It recovers from partial failures in the server, by eventually achieving total success of all sub-operations.

This works no matter how many levels of client-server relationships we're on. Consider a tree of operations like this:

graph LR
  frontend --> backend
  backend --> database
  backend --> cache
  backend --> microservice
  microservice --> dbcreate[database create]
  microservice --> mailer
  microservice --> dbsave[database save]


Say that a request from frontend to backend results in requests to all those systems, as part of the backend's operation. Consider what happens if mailer fails:

sequenceDiagram
  participant frontend
  participant backend
  participant database
  participant cache
  participant microservice
  participant mailerdb as database
  participant mailer

  frontend ->> backend: do op 1
  backend ->> database: set foo=42 from op 1
  database ->> backend: OK, stored
  backend ->> cache: set foo=42 from op 1
  cache ->> backend: OK, stored
  backend ->> microservice: send email from op 1
  microservice ->> mailerdb: create new email from op 1
  mailerdb ->> microservice: OK, created
  microservice ->> mailer: send a mail from op 1
  mailer ->> microservice: ðŸš¨ crash! ðŸš¨
  microservice ->> backend: ðŸš¨ crash! ðŸš¨
  backend ->> frontend: ðŸš¨ crash! ðŸš¨

  Note left of frontend: Well, let's retry

  frontend ->> backend: do op 1
  backend ->> database: set foo=42 from op 1
  database ->> backend: already did!
  backend ->> cache: set foo=42 from op 1
  cache ->> backend: already did!
  backend ->> microservice: send email from op 1
  microservice ->> mailerdb: create new email from op 1
  mailerdb ->> microservice: already did!
  microservice ->> mailer: send a mail from op 1
  mailer ->> microservice: OK, sent
  microservice ->> mailerdb: mark email as sent from op 1
  mailerdb ->> microservice: OK, done
  microservice ->> backend: OK, done
  backend ->> frontend: OK, done


Can we trust clients to retry?
The problem with this approach to fixing partial failures it that usually you need the client to retry. If it doesn't, then your system might be stuck in an intermediate state.
If the client is a frontend, e. g. a browser or a mobile phone, you need an intermediate that reliably retries on failure if you really care about reaching a consistent state, because state in user devices is not durable.
You can also just have a garbage collector.

Canceling work
The client could attempt to notify the server if they stop being interested in an operation. The server should then propagate this notification to their backends and crash the request handler. This prevents unnecessary work.
A robust way of doing so is by breaking the connection. This is what happens if the user closes the browser tab, for example, so you can take advantage of that.
Beware of inconsistent state, though. A broken connection means the client won't retry anymore, so consider that, as above.

002-distributed-data/01-contradictions.h.title: Contradictions
002-distributed-data/01-contradictions.h.body:
Contradictions
Frontends outnumber the backend
So far, we've studied the conversations between a frontend and a backend, that is, a computer running a frontend program and a computer running a backend program, including the derived conversations between this backend and other backend servers (databases, mailers, etc.).

graph LR
  frontend --- backend
  backend --- database
  backend --- cache
  backend --- mailer
  backend --- ...


But, of course, we know that's usually not all participants in our little distributed system. It actually looks like this:

graph LR
  frontend1["frontend"] --- backend
  frontend2["frontend"] --- backend
  frontend3["frontend"] --- backend
  frontend4["frontend"] --- backend
  frontend5["frontend"] --- backend
  frontend6["frontend"] --- backend
  frontend7["frontend"] --- backend
  frontend8["... more frontends ..."] --- backend
  backend --- database
  backend --- cache
  backend --- mailer
  backend --- ...


Unless we have a single user, we have many frontend computers talking with our backend at the same time.
Side note: beware of your development setup bias
Actually, there's a scenario in which you'll usually have a single frontend talking to your backend at any given time: when developing. You'll typically open your browser, go to localhost:something, and see if whatever you're building works.
This is a huge source of bias. You should be aware at all times that your local system reflects only very poorly your real production system. Some ways in which your local environment is different:

You will rarely experience contradictions.
The local network is very fast and reliable. (In particular, if you're targeting mobile users, I'd say you must use a network limiter.)
It runs in a laptop instead of a server, or a series of servers. Hardware is different.
It probably isn't as virtualized as the server.
The server sustains way more load.
The server is probably running other programs that may steal resources from your backend.

Frontends share memory
If every communication between a frontend and a backend were completely isolated from the others, then this wouldn't be a problem at all. But, usually, there is some shared memory in place: a database, a cache.
This opens up the possibility of contradictions. A participant may assume that the shared memory has something in it, but in reality it has something else.
Sequential, concurrent, distributed
Actually, this chapter isn't really about distributed systems. As we've seen, distributed systems are all about communication through an unreliable network. But, even if communication happened through a completely reliable network with guaranteed bounded delay, we would still have several participants sharing memory, and thus the possibility of contradictions.
Everything in this chapter actually applies to concurrent systems, of which distributed systems are a subset.
Sequential system

A sequential system, or just process, is the basic building block of computing: some instructions run one after another, reading and storing bits in a piece of memory that nobody else uses, in a completely reliable way. A read or a write to that memory effectively stops the world.
Concurrent system
If we take several processes running at the same time and give them access to the same piece of memory, we get a concurrent system. This piece of memory is also accessed in a completely reliable way.

Note that, by leaving each other "messages" in the shared memory, concurrent processes may communicate. In fact, this capacity of reliable communication between processes is the really fundamental thing about concurrent systems. In practice, concurrent processes communicate through shared memory, but on some programming models this shared memory is abstracted away.
Distributed system
When we make several processes running at the same time communicate through an unreliable medium, we get a distributed system.

Distributed systems are inherently concurrent, since we find in them sequential processes communicating with each other. But we may find concurrent systems that are not distributed.
Related events
When processes run, they produce events, things that happen: this piece of memory gets read, this gets written, this page gets printed, etc. Computing is nothing but a succession of such events.
When considering a sequential process, all events have an intrinsic, implicit relationship between them: each event either happens before or after another event.
Events can have an additional relationship: one event may depend on another. If event A wouldn't have happened if event B wouldn't have happened before A, we say that B causes A, or that A depends on B. We call this a causal relationship.
If two events aren't causally related, then it doesn't matter in which order they are run: the end state of the process's memory afterwards will be exactly the same.
Consider the following assignments in a sequential system:
foo = 42
bar = qux * 2

The end result of those is exactly the same as:
bar = qux * 2
foo = 42

Now, consider something like this:
foo = 42
bar = foo * 2

Now we can't just swap the two assignments, since the effects of the second assignment depends on the assignment of foo happening before.
When we introduce concurrent processes into the equation, we open up the possibility of two events not being bound by a happens-before relationship. By running them in different concurrent processes, neither happens before the other.

If two events aren't causally related, then A and B may happen in any order, including at the same time.

But causally related event must be also related in time.

If event A depends on event B, then B must happen before event A.

So, if event A depends on event B, must A and B happen in the same sequential process? Not necessarily.

Given that event A depends on event B, A and B can happen in two different concurrent processes if the process that runs A communicates A to the process that runs B.

When two concurrent processes communicate in a controlled manner, establishing a happens-before relationship between the events one has produced and the other will produce, then we say they synchronize.
Concurrent systems in the wild
Time-sharing processes
Your computer is, at any time, running a bunch of programs at the same time. Each instance of a running program is called a process.
Each process has its own address space, a chunk of memory that only that process can access.
The operating system is in charge of making a process execute by letting it run in a CPU for a while, then hitting pause on it, letting another process run in its place, pausing that one, and so on. It does so for all available CPU cores in the machine. By doing this fast enough, if effectively looks like all processes are executing at the same time, as concurrent processes. This is called scheduling.
The OS provides tools to achieve inter-process communication (IPC). Some of them are:

Files and pipes.
Shared memory (shm).
Network sockets, either in a real network, in localhost (a "virtual" network), or as domain sockets.
Signals.

Threads
Actually, the OS doesn't schedule processes, but threads. A process has at least one thread (called the main thread), but it may spawn more of those.
Each thread has its own stack, but they all share address space, so they can do things like reading and writing to the same variables.
A thread can communicate with another thread by writing in a shared variable that the other thread then reads.
Writing or reading a variable is usually not an atomic operation. In the middle of writing or reading, the thread might be paused by the operating system. If then another thread reads it, it may see a half-written variable, or, by writing on it, cause the original thread to see so when it comes back. This can happen too if two threads are running in different CPUs and happen to access the variable at the same time.
To fix this, the system provides atomic synchronization mechanisms such as mutexes, semaphores, and condition variables.
Event loop
This is the JavaScript model: there's a single thread, but, when encountering a blocking operation (a network operation, an access to disk, a wait), instead of waiting for it to finish, a callback is registered.
This callback will be enqueued for being called when the blocking operation for which it was registered finishes, producing an event.
The running thread eventually finishes the current call stack, ideally pretty quickly since it doesn't wait for anything blocking to finish. When it does, then the event loop takes over control of the the thread. It looks in the queue of callbacks that want to be called, pops one of them, and calls it. The process just repeats until the process dies.
When you don't know in which order two callbacks will be called by the event loop, they are for all intents and purposes concurrent.
Two concurrent callbacks can communicate by closing over the same variable and accessing it from both.
Since there's a single thread, accessing a variable is atomic. This makes things easier, but bugs based on assuming that variables don't change in between callbacks can still happen, since they can break causality.
Green threads
This is kind of a hybrid between threads and an event loop. As far as concurrency is concerned, though, they are basically equivalent to threads, except that, depending on the exact model, accessing variables without other synchronization mechanisms in place may or may not be atomic.
Race conditions
A race condition is a type of bug in which we fail to codify the causality of two events properly. We wanted event A to depend on event B, but instead it ends up depending on some other event.
Race conditions are hard because our programming languages are inherently sequential. We tend to codify causal dependencies as just happen-before relationships; that is, if we want A to depend on B, our programming languages lead us to believe that we just have to do B after A. This doesn't take into account events that may have taken place in between B and A happen in our process, which could break relationship.
Think about this pair of concurrent processes:
Process 1
foo = 42; // A
bar = foo * 2; // B

Process 2
foo = 1337; // C

If foo is a shared variable of some kind, and you intended event B to depend on event A, then this code has, at least, one race condition, because B might be depending on C instead.
Synchronization mechanisms
To avoid race conditions, we need to synchronize concurrent processes so that the intended causality relationships are enforced. Let's examine a few ways of synchronizing.
Atomic operations
An operation is atomic when no concurrent event can affect it.
Locks
Locks, also called mutexes (from mutual exclusion), are probably the most ubiquitous synchronization mechanism. All others can be implemented with it.
A lock is a shared object that concurrent threads acquire and then release, with the invariant that only one process may have the lock at the same time.
Our example above could be fixed by doing this:
Process 1
lock(); // L1
foo = 42; // A
bar = foo * 2; // B
unlock(); // U1

Process 2
lock(); // L2
foo = 1337; // C
unlock(); // U2

This ensures that B actually depends on A. The key is that there's an enforced happens-before relationship between the whole group of events L1+A+B+U1 and L2+C+U2. We don't know the order in which the two groups will happen, but we know that events from one process won't happen before events from the other have happened.
Locks are tricky to get right: you can fall into deadlocks if by accidentally making a process that has the lock depend on itself to release the lock to continue.
Atomic load and writeÂ¡
In JavaScript, reading and writing to variables is atomic. In databases, load and writing a single object is also typically atomic. In other runtimes that preempt threads or allows concurrent reads and writes, additional ceremony is necessary.
Increment and decrement
Again, since in JavaScript you know that everything that happens within a function call is atomic, doing this:
a = a + 1;

is atomic. But in other runtimes, including most databases, a concurrent process may assign some value Y for a in between a is read with some value X and then assigned to X + 1. Then, value Y will be lost.
Compare-and-swap
Atomically execute something like:
function compareAndSwap(newValue, expectedCurrent) {
  let current = a;
  if (current == expectedCurrent) {
    a = newValue;
  }
  return current;
}

This is a powerful primitive that lets us check that our assumption about the current value of the shared variable is still what we thought it is, probably from a previous read, before setting it to a new value. This prevents losing writes.
A particularly useful way of using this is "set if unset and return current value". This lets concurrent process agree on some value, it doesn't matter which.
A variant, compare-and-set, doesn't return the current value, but just whether our assumption was true:
function compareAndSet(newValue, expectedCurrent) {
  let current = a;
  if (current == expectedCurrent) {
    a = newValue;
  }
  return current == expectedCurrent;
}

MongoDB's findAndModify implements a compare-and-set operation.
Optimistic locking
Transactions
Isolation levels
Distributed synchronization
Distributed locks
Distributed transactions
Two-phase commit
Handling concurrent requests
The single-threaded model
As championed by Redis. Just run every request sequentially. Be fast. Trivially serializable.
The event loop model
Use a single thread, but make the reaction to a blocking operation happen latter, letting other requests sneak in in the meantime.
The (green?) threaded model
Each request is handled by a separate thread or even a process. There might be a thread pool, or one thread per concurrent process.
Race detection
Deterministic merges
Writes declare read dependencies

002-distributed-data/02-persistent-state.title: Persistent state
002-distributed-data/02-persistent-state.body:
Persistent state
How real is our success confirmation?
We've seen that, when someone asks us to do some operation, either:

We do it completely and respond with a success confirmation (an acknowledgment, or ack, for short).
We do it partially (or not at all) and crash.

From the perspective of the client, we know that we can't make any assumption about the success of the operation if we don't get a confirmation response in time.
But if we do get an ack, what does it mean, exactly?
The simplistic assumption to make is that all consequences of our request are, at and after that point, completely and permanently in effect.
For instance, I might assume that, after I get confirmation that foo=42 has been saved in a database, and nobody else overwrites such save, then every subsequent query for foo to the database will get 42.

sequenceDiagram
  participant c1 as client 1
  participant db as database
  participant c2 as client 2
  participant c3 as client 3

  Note right of db: foo=13

  c2 ->> db: get foo
  db ->> c2: 13

  c1 ->> db: set foo=42
  Note right of db: foo=42
  db ->> c1: ok

  c2 ->> db: get foo
  db ->> c2: 42

  c3 ->> db: get foo
  db ->> c3: 42

  c1 ->> db: get foo
  db ->> c1: 42


Sadly, this is isn't realistic.
When hard disks break
The database is stored in a hard disk somewhere. At some point, this hard disk will stop working.
In this scenario, it's obvious that the assumption that we did above doesn't hold anymore. The acknowledgment that we get from the database just means that subsequent queries probably will get the value we stored. But it can also be lost forever.
Needless to say, a system that just loses its data from time to time is probably providing a terrible service, depending on our needs.
So there's a tension between:

The fact that disks die.
Our preference for acknowledged operation's consequences to persist in time.

Backups
A first step to address the problem of disks dying is to make backups. If a disk dies, then we just swap it by one its backups. (We call this process a failover.)
Considering just one backup (you probably want more than one):

sequenceDiagram
  participant c1 as client 1
  participant db as database
  participant backup as backup
  participant c2 as client 2

  Note right of db: Database:foo=13
  Note right of backup: Backup:foo=13

  c1 ->> db: set foo=42
  Note right of db: Database:foo=42
  Note right of backup: Backup:foo=13
  db ->> c1: ok

  c2 ->> db: get foo
  db ->> c2: 42

  Note right of db: Backup time!
  db ->> backup: start backup (somehow)
  Note right of db: Database:foo=42
  Note right of backup: Backup:foo=42
  backup ->> db: ok

  Note right of db: Database is dead! Backup will serve from now on.

  c1 ->> backup: get foo
  backup ->> c1: 42


This is definitely an improvement: in case of failure, we fall back to the last backed up state of the database, not to emptiness.
Continuous backup of changes = replication
Once we've decided we're doing backups, we're faced with a question: how and when should we make them?
The simplest way of backing up a database is to just copy all the data at any given time, from time to time.

sequenceDiagram
  participant clients
  participant db
  participant backup

  clients ->> db: foo=42
  Note right of db: Database:foo=42
  Note right of backup: Backup:
  clients ->> db: bar="baz"
  Note right of db: Database:foo=42,bar="baz"
  Note right of backup: Backup:
  clients ->> db: qux=13.37
  Note right of db: Database:foo=42,bar="baz",qux=13.37
  Note right of backup: Backup:

  Note right of db: Backup time!

  db ->> backup: all the data
  Note right of db: Database:foo=42,bar="baz",qux=13.37
  Note right of backup: Backup:foo=42,bar="baz",qux=13.37

  clients ->> db: a=123
  Note right of db: Database:foo=42,bar="baz",qux=13.37,a=123
  Note right of backup: Backup:foo=42,bar="baz",qux=13.37
  clients ->> db: foo=0
  Note right of db: Database:foo=0,bar="baz",qux=13.37,a=123
  Note right of backup: Backup:foo=42,bar="baz",qux=13.37

  Note right of db: Backup time!

  db ->> backup: all the data
  Note right of db: Database:foo=0,bar="baz",qux=13.37,a=123
  Note right of backup: Backup:foo=0,bar="baz",qux=13.37,a=123


However, it's easy to see this way is not ideal:

It's probably not very efficient. Lots of data won't have changed between a backup and the next, so copying the same data again is a waste of resources.
It introduces a lengthy period of inconsistency between a backup and the next. If the database fails during that interval, we'll fall back to data that can be badly outdated.

What should we do instead? We can emit an event with each change that is processed as soon as possible. Instead of copying the data, we copy the events that change the data.
This is what we usually understand by replication. The "backup" databases are then called replicas or secondary (or slaves, which is failing into disuse), while the database that accepts write requests is called leader or primary (or master, which is also falling into disuse).

sequenceDiagram
  participant clients
  participant db
  participant backup

  clients ->> db: foo=42
  Note right of db: Database:foo=42
  db ->> backup: foo=42
  Note right of backup: Backup:foo=42
  clients ->> db: bar="baz"
  Note right of db: Database:foo=42,bar="baz"
  db ->> backup: bar="baz"
  Note right of backup: Backup:foo=42,bar="baz"
  clients ->> db: qux=13.37
  Note right of db: Database:foo=42,bar="baz",qux=13.37
  db ->> backup: qux=13.37
  Note right of backup: Backup:foo=42,bar="baz",qux=13.37
  clients ->> db: a=123
  Note right of db: Database:foo=42,bar="baz",qux=13.37,a=123
  db ->> backup: a=123
  Note right of backup: Backup:foo=42,bar="baz",qux=13.37,a=123
  clients ->> db: foo=0
  Note right of db: Database:foo=0,bar="baz",qux=13.37,a=123
  db ->> backup: foo=0
  Note right of backup: Backup:foo=0,bar="baz",qux=13.37,a=123


Sync vs. async
In the last chapter, we saw that two concurrent processes can collaborate by synchronizing, that is, establishing a point of communication after which they can safely set causal relationships between their new events and the other process's older events.
In simpler words, you let another process see some of the data that your events produced, so that it can do something with that data.
A request and its response establish a window of synchronicity between the participants:

The request carries data from the client to the server.
The response, at the very least, signals to the client that the server did something with that data.

Those are two synchronization events: the request can do things as a consequence of what happened on the client, and then, the client can do things as a consequence of the server having processed its request.

With this in mind, we can categorize the events that happen while handling a request (that is, in the server, between a request is received and its response is sent) as:

Synchronous: The event happens in this window, before the response is sent.
Asynchronous: Not synchronous. The event happens concurrently with the window: it may happen before or after the response is sent.

This is a useful distinction to which we will return in future chapters.
To consider a operation carried out as part of processing the request to be synchronous means that the server waits for its completion (either as an ack, or as a timeout) before responding to the client.
On the other hand, an asynchronous operation may be initiated inside the request handler, but it is not waited for completion before responding.
As often, there's no right way to do things; both doing things synchronously or asynchronously have their advantages.
Replication strategies
Synchronous replication
Synchronous replication means that we don't acknowledge a save to the database as successful until saves to all the replicas are acknowledged as successful too.
This is useful because then, if a failover occurs, we're sure that we won't see an outdated version of the data, ie. a version that was overwritten at some point in the past by a successfully acknowledged write to the database.
Remember the assumption we used above?

For instance, I might assume that, after I get confirmation that foo=42 has been saved in a database, and nobody else overwrites such save, then every subsequent query for foo to the database will get 42.

Under synchronous replication, this holds while there's at least one replica of the data accessible somewhere. As it is extremely unlikely that all replicas are dead at any given time, this strategy basically makes writes unforgettable, so it makes this assumption reasonable.
This strategy has two downsides:

If any single replica fails, we're under a partial failure scenario: some replicas may have the new data while others may not, so the system is left in an inconsistent state. The client needs to retry the operation to restore consistency.
The latency (the time since the client sends a request until it receives a response) of the whole operation is bounded by the latency of the slowest of the replicas.

Note that this is equivalent to the let-it-crash strategy we've seen before for partial failures.
Asynchronous replication
Under asynchronous replication, we acknowledge a save after we've persistently stored it in our primary database's disk, but we don't wait for saves to replicas to complete.
This allows us to respond quickly to a write request, but then we have no guarantee about whether or when the replicas will process the write.
Replication lag
As we'll study in detail in future chapters, responding quickly by doing part of the work asynchronously doesn't magically make the work free. We basically trade off reduced latency by increased memory consumption and/or lost data.
In this case, since a write is acknowledged by the primary until it is processes by all async replicas, we need to store the fact that it happened somewhere, so that the replicas can consume the event from there. This somewhere is called the replication log.
The amount of time between a write enters this log and it is consumed by the slowest replica is called replication lag.
If one or more replicas become slow for some reason, or if they can't keep up with the pace of writes to the database, the replication lag will increase and the replication log will grow indefinitely, until it is too big to fit in wherever it is kept.
At that point, we can either start dropping data from it or stop accepting new writes.
Reading from replicas
So far, replicas have been just sitting there, keeping themselves up to date and waiting for a failover to being promoted to primary and have a chance to do something useful. But what if we put them to use before that?
We've seen two ways replicas may not be up-to-date with the leader:

Under asynchronous replication, the replication lag may not be zero.
Under synchronous replication, a write may have failed, leaving some replicas outdated.

If we can afford reading data that is not completely up-to-date, we can use replicas to perform reads.
This reduces reads-per-second in our primary database.
Leaderless databases
OK, so what if we don't just allow reads from replicas, but also writes?
Well, to begin with, they stop being replicas. They're no longer storing replicated data that is also stored somewhere else, but, for a while at least, they hold data that no other machine holds.
When more than one machine accept writes, we no longer have leaders: we have a leaderless database.
In this scenario, typically all machines that accept writes act as replicas to all other machines that accept writes. (There might be additional read-only replicas.)
Why would we want to do this?

Failover is trivial: just retry the write in another machine.
We can scale by adding more machines: each machine will receive only a portion of the requests.

Quorum
Being leaderless is independent of the replication strategy used, but it opens the door to a middle ground between synchronous and asynchronous replication: write synchronously to, and read synchronously from, only a majority of the machines, instead of all of them. This is called quorum consistency.
They key is that, if you write to a majority of machines, then a read to a majority of machines will necessarily overlap at least in one machine with the newest write. The read can then select the newest version of the retrieved data.
This greatly reduces the chances of inconsistency, at the expense of making writes and reads more expensive, as they need to go to more machines.
Note that inconsistency may still occur: some machines that acknowledged the write can then die, and then the new majority may not include any machine with that write. Also, the partial failure scenario of synchronous replication can still occur here.
Dealing with conflicts
Accepting writes in more than one machine at the same time means they can contradict each other. What happens if one machine accepts foo=42 while concurrently another machine accepts foo=13? Eventually, all machines in the system will be presented with both writes. What should they do?
Last write wins
The easiest approach is to not deal with the conflict at all: make some choice between two conflicting writes and discard the other. This choice is made in all machines in the system, and needs to be deterministic so that the system keeps being eventually consistent, ie. machines don't contradict each other in the long run.
The usual way to choose one write over the other is that writes are tagged with the time they were first processed. Then, each node just chooses the write that seems to have happened more recently.
Note that, as clocks aren't perfectly synchronized between machines, this may not actually be the case; but, even if it was, we could very easily be losing writes.
Consider a counter that starts at zero. If the system receives T1: counter=1 (T1, T2, etc., being the time tag), then some client reads this and increases the counter by writing T2: counter=2, then all is fine. But if the system receives T1: counter=1, and concurrently some client reads the counter and sees counter=0, and then attempts to increase the counter by writing T2: counter=1, then the final state that will eventually be chosen by all machines is T2: counter=1. We have lost an increase.
Read repair
Another technique is that, on noticing conflicting writes, store both, and let clients that read the data later perform a read repair by clarifying which final value should be kept, following whatever logic they choose.
But how can we detect conflicting writes?
In the example above, if a client sends T1: counter=1 and another client sends T2: counter=1, we know that there's a conflict: we have two increases, but the second client didn't take into account the first, concurrent increase. However, if we see T1: counter=1 and T2: counter=2, then there's no conflict: the final value of the counter coincides with the amount of increases performed, so the second client must have seen the T1: counter=1, and derived T2: counter=2 from it.
The trick is to tag each write with the version they're based on. There are several ways of doing this with different properties, but they broadly called logical clocks. See Why Logical Clocks are Easy if you're interested in details.
In the example above, in the conflicting scenario, the database would store both T1: counter=1 and T2: counter=1. When a client then reads the counter, it will be presented with both values. It can then merge them with a logic that makes sense; in this case, it can add their values to get a total count of T3: counter=2. This will be sent back to the database, which can then discard the conflicting values and store the merged value instead.
CRDTs
CRDT stands for Conflict-free Replicated Data Type. Those are types on which all operations are:

Commutative.
Associative.
Idempotent.

This means that processing any number of writes to the same CRDT yields the same result, no matter in which order they're applied, or even how many times each of them is performed.
A set to which you can only add items is a trivial example of a CRDT. But there are others, for many useful scenarios.
CRDTs have the additional nice property of being idempotent, which is a property that many databases just sweep under the rug but that we've seen how important it is.
Linearizability: consistent-first robustness
There are leaderless systems that act as if they were a single machine with at all times, even if some machines fail.
This property of a whole distributed system acting as a single machine that processes operations one after another and keeps the data consistent between one operation and the next is called linearizability.
In practice, this is achieved with databases that achieve consensus. ZooKeeper, etcd and Consul are examples of such databases.
The downside is that such systems are usually very slow, and can't process that many writes per second. But for data that is small, changes not that frequently and is critical to keep fully consistent, linearizability is usually worth it.
This is an active area of research, however, and recently more databases are appearing with this or slightly lower consistency guarantees while still being distributed, fault-tolerant, and fast. Look into Spanner, FoundationDB and CockroachDB as examples of such databases.
Durability vs. latency
The ability to not lose data once you've acknowledged as written is called durability.
Roughly speaking, techniques that increase durability also increase latency. Making data durable means saving it deeper, in more reliable places, that will survive a reboot or even a whole disk failure.
There are systems that optimize for latency rather than durability. That's what caches usually do, for example: since the data they store is also stored (durably) somewhere else, or it can be recomputed, or we can afford to just lose it, they don't bother storing it in disk: they keep it in memory, which is way faster to access than the disk.
Partitioning
As you can imagine, storing data gets hard as a system gets more users. You get:

More requests per second.
More volume of data: queries need to search more data to get a result.
Data may no longer fit in a single disk.
Replicas may no longer be able to keep up with the pace of writes.

Sooner or later, you will have to not just store the same data in several places (replication), but also put different data in different places (partitioning).
This reduces the load in each partition, effectively eliminating bottlenecks and single points of failure. It is key to achieve a scalable system.
Partitioning by keeping separate databases
This is the easiest way to partition your data: just keep separate, completely independent databases.
