The downside is that you can't make queries that search all your data.
Partitioning a single database
You can also partition a single database, so that you're able to query the whole database. This usually is handled by the database system you're using.
Indexing a partitioned database
Often, we want to query data not by its primary key (IDs), but by other fields (name, some date, etc.).
We do this efficiently by declaring an index. An index makes queries efficient roughly by making an ordered list of data; then, a query doesn't need to search all documents/rows/objects, just those within the limits of what we're querying.
Keeping an index in sync with the data is easy in a single partition, but things get more involved in a partitioned database. There are two main approaches.
Partitioned index
The index, ie. the list, lives in its own machine. Each time a write occurs, an additional write needs to be performed to each of the affected indexes's machines to keep it updated.
Slow writes, fast reads, as a query by an indexed field only needs to look up one machine.
Scatter-gather
Keep partial indexes in the same partition in which the data lives.
Fast writes, slow reads, as a query by an indexed field needs to go to all partitions for their partial indexes, then merge their results.

002-distributed-data/03-doing-things-lat.title: Doing things later

002-distributed-data/04-operation-orient.title: Operation-oriented databases
002-distributed-data/04-operation-orient.body:
Operation-oriented databases
Servers serving services
Although there are many ways computer can communicate with each other, in the Web-oriented world we mostly deal with client-server relationships.
In this model, there is a service that the server provides and the client consumes.
For example, MongoDB provides a service to store your data while trying not to lose it too much. It does so through an API, which clients often interact with through a client library.
In our case, the backend exposes all the functionality the frontend needs to activate as a result of user interaction, usually through an API built on top of HTTP and/or WebSockets, as those are the technologies that can be used from web browsers.
But what is the backend exactly? Is it a single program? Is it a system of programs? Well, that's on us to design and implement. Let's see which choices we have, and their tradeoffs.
The monolithic backend
The no-brainer approach to building a backend is to design a system with the following components:

Generic services that handle some functionality for us: databases, mailers, file storage, reverse proxies, etc.
A program that implements app-specific logic to handle requests from frontends.
Maybe some peripheral programs that run periodically (cronjobs) or consume jobs from a message queue.

This is the monolith approach: you have a single, big program that knows how to do everything.
A constellation of microservices
The thing is, successful software projects tend to grow:

New functionality needs to be added.
More existing functionality needs to be modified or extended.
More people are put to work on it.
They get more users and more load.

As time passes, and the project grows and grows, the friction required to grow in all those dimensions increases, mainly because things that ought to be independent end up affecting each other.
Microservices is about reducing that friction by:

Splitting your backend's service in several.
Have specialized programs for each one.
Have them collaborate as a distributed system.

Hoping that:

New functionality is added as a new service, or as small changes to a small number of services.
Changes affect a single service or only to a small number of services.
Teams can focus on a single service or a handful of them, without getting affected by other teams working in other services.
Each service is designed specifically for the kind of scale it needs to support, and the kind of mission they perform.

The three first points are more about development than actual production concerns, but the fourth its just a hard technical reality: parts of your application probably have different technical needs than others, and having them as separate programs makes it easier to provide them with the resources that fits them best.
Are microservices worth the trouble? It seems so, because organizations tend to naturally move towards them.
Where to split?
The criteria you use to assign responsibilities to microservices is pretty important. If you get it wrong, you can end up negating most of the benefits of doing microservices in the first place; such scenarios are called distributed monolith.
Entity-oriented
This is maybe the most obvious way of segregating responsibility, since it's the way code is usually split in a codebase.
You identify entities in your domain, such as User, Company, Car, Receipt and whatnot. And then you create a service for each.
Splitting like this, by itself, is likely to get you into a distributed monolith scenario.
Probably, each service has a database where it creates, reads, updates and deletes the entities they're in charge of managing, with all their fields. (This database may be shared among services, introducing even more coupling between them.)
The thing is, business logic tends to affect a lot of entities. For anything that needs to happen, you'll end up doing lots of requests to lots of services. Things get even worse if you need anything like a join: for example, retrieve a list of Users with their Companies.
Furthermore, the logic will be moving around lots of data it's not actually interested in. A single operation interacts with only a subset of that data. And data that "belongs to" an entity (fields) tends to accrue over time.
Operation-oriented
If we shift our approach to "what we want to do with the data?", things get much better.
With this approach, the data that is kept together is the data that an operation, or a bunch of closely-related operations, needs to use.
The services are then in charge of those operations, and rarely have to talk directly to other services, except to perform other operations as opposed to just to access some data.
This usually means that you no longer have a single, cohesive User, Company or Car in a database somewhere. Instead, the data about an entity is distributed, maybe duplicated, in several databases.
This also makes it easier to assign appropriate resources to each operation. Some fields of an entity may be updated several times per second, while others are updated very unusually or never. Maybe some operation is only concerned with data that is active right now (for example, a delivery tracking service of some sort), and thus it only needs small database for it without much partitioning, while another service deals with past data with a more appropriate database.
As always, those are general rules that shouldn't be applied blindly. Both entity-oriented and operation-oriented can be mixed up, depending on the use case. Having data about a single entity in several places presents challenges that the entity-oriented approach doesn't.
Criticality-oriented
Another criteria to consider is: "how important is to keep this service up?".
Separating services by how critical they are makes it easier to focus resources on them.
Getting data you're interested in through events
With a entity-oriented responsibility segregation, it's obvious how to get the data you need for an operation: you go to the entity's service, which holds all its data. But once you go the operation-oriented route, the data you're interested in may have been produced in any other operation-oriented service. How do you get access to it?
If every service that produces data (and updates to data) sends events, then every service interested in that data can listen to those events, take exactly what they want, and save that in their own database, in order to later do something with them when requested.
Consider the delivery tracking example from above. Say you have the following use cases:

A customer orders a delivery for a package with some dimensions and weight.
A route through logistic centers is decided for every delivery.
When a delivery reaches a logistic center or something, an operator scans it and a time and place update takes place.
Logistic centers need to be paid for every package they handle, daily. Heavier and bigger packages cost more.
Finally, the customer is charged money based on how long it took the package to reach the destination. (Faster is more expensive!)
The customer can see the list of deliveries it has made in the past.

We can create services for each one of those operations, and have them communicate through events.

When a customer orders a delivery, a service validates it and emits a DeliveryOrdered event, by putting it in a message queue.
Another service, let's call it delivery-router, consumes DeliveryOrdered events, and, based on its origin and destination, goes through the list of available logistic centers to calculate a route, and then emits a DeliveryAssignedRoute event.
Whenever somebody from the delivery company adds, updates or removes a logistic center, a LogisticCenterUpdated event is emitted. delivery-routes consumes such events, to keep its list of logistic centers updated. This events comes with lots of data about the logistic center (name of the company that operates it, tariffs, etc.), so delivery-routes only stores the relevant data: its location, maybe which kind of packages they can handle, etc.
Another service listens for DeliveryAssignedRoute events and notifies logistic centers about an incoming package.
When an operator in a logistic center scans a package, a service handles that, validates it and sends a DeliveryReachedLogisticCenter event with the logistic center ID, the delivery ID, and the time.
Another service listens for DeliveryReachedLogisticCenter to decide how much it should pay a logistic center for a delivery. For this, it also needs the center's tariffs and the package's dimensions, so it also listens forLogisticCenterUpdated and DeliveryOrdered events, taking the data it needs.
The service that charges customers listens to DeliveryOrdered, (to know when a delivery starts), DeliveryAssignedRoute (to know which logistic center is the last) and DeliveryReachedLogisticCenter (to know when the last logistic center is reached). It then emits an invoice, and maybe calls an external service to do the payment. It emits a DeliveryCharged event.
Another service listens to all this, integrates the information, and arranges it so that it can be inspected later by customers in a web page.

Data consistency in times of microservices
The operation-oriented, event-based approach comes with a cost: events are often delivered asynchronously, so have to be very careful about how we handle events.
This often means that what is true in one service is not true in another service... yet. It will be in the future, when events propagate the data to all affected services. This is called eventual consistency. We must be careful to know how this affects our operations, and where we can and can't afford it.
For example, in order to validate a money transfer, we need to know the balance of the user's account right now. We can't afford the service that handles that to base that decision on old data.
Event sourcing
It is often desirable to have a single source of truth. When data is denormalized, we can get into a situation in which different versions of it contradict each other.
Data, ultimately, derives from events that create, update and delete it. Those events are unique, immutable, and either ordered by causal relationships or independent from each other, as we've seen.
If we store such events somewhere, we can later reconstruct the data they're supposed to produce. If a service becomes out-of-sync with the events as they happen due to some problem, we can "replay" those events from the events storage to regenerate a consistent view of the resulting data.
This technique is called event sourcing.

003-backends-in-the-wild/.title: Backends in the wild
003-backends-in-the-wild/.body:
Backends in the wild
Robust backends recap
We're getting close now to completing our picture of how a robust backend looks. Let's quickly recap where we're at:

An operation timing out or getting a transient error means that the client doesn't know whether it has completed successfully.
By retrying until we get success confirmation, we ensure an operation eventually succeeds. But this is not free:
Operations need to be made idempotent, so that successful operations observed as failed can be retried without unwanted effects.
Since clients are usually not reliable, to really ensure success, we need to, which complicates the system.


It's crucial to establish a exhaustive and well-defined protocol in the form of an API that works as a contract between clients and servers.
All possible errors that the operations could produce must be fully defined by this protocol.
They must not expose irrelevant details to the client.
They must expose enough information for clients to handle them gracefully at the right level.
At the very least, application-level errors must be easily differentiated from transient errors due to system conditions.


Details from underlying protocols, such as TCP connection termination, should be gracefully handled and have well-defined effects.
When extended, the changes to the API should avoid breaking clients of the previous version.


The let it crash systems design principle states that, since the system must be ready to handle timeouts and crashes anyway, we can simplify error handling in a system prone to partial failure of an operation by immediately crashing in all levels of the operation when an inner-level operation fails, and letting an outermost level that reliable monitorizes the operation handle all crashes gracefully.
Since distributed systems are inherently concurrent, we must be on the lookout for race conditions by ensuring a well-defined order of operations.
Atomic operations are operations that either succeed fully or not at all, as a single event, so no concurrent events can affect their outcome.
Transactions is how we usually achieve atomicity in a database, but we must be very careful to choose the right isolation level to avoid assuming a more relaxed meaning of atomic.


Locks are the most flexible way of avoiding race conditions, but they are not atomic, so they're prone to partial failure and deadlocks (two processes waiting on each other to release a lock).


Since machines or disks can die at any time and data held on them can be lost, we must replicate the data in several machines/disks in order to make a durable system (a system that doesn't lose data).
It takes time for data to replicate, so in the meantime data can be inconsistent (two machines may contradict each other on what's the state of the system). You must choose the replication mechanism with the right consistency guarantees for your use case, taking its cost into account.


We can move part of the work into message queues to be done later.
Message queues can be made durable and usually retry failed deliveries, so we can use them to ensure an operation eventually succeeds.
They allow us to trade off queue length for other resources when requests rate grows.
They allow us to acknowledge requests as successful more quickly, but we must be careful to define that such success doesn't mean all the work has been already carried out.


By splitting a component of the system in several components, we can assign each of them the right resources to perform their work optimally.
In particular, we can split data in several databases, focused on the operations they must support, and keep them consistent through an event-based architecture.



Backends meet the physical world
The main piece missing is that backends run in real machines with limited resources and under changing conditions.
We've talked about failure in a very broad sense: what to do when anything fails. But we've seen little about how these failures, and the mechanisms we put in place to resist them, interact with the environment our backends run on.
We'll see how a good relationship with a changing environment with limited resources is the crucial missing piece for not just working around problems, but also for being able to prevent them and, even more importantly, for stopping them from spreading so much that even our recovery mechanisms break.

003-backends-in-the-wild/01-computers-di.title: Computers disappear
003-backends-in-the-wild/01-computers-di.body:
Computers disappear
Disposable computers in robust systems
As we've seen, there's no escape to the fact that computers die from time to time.
A single computer dying may be a tragedy, especially if you didn't hit "Save" recently. However, a million interconnected computers dying over time is just distributed systems.
As designers, it's our job to make our system robust. This requires planning in advance that individual computers participating on it will die.
A robust system is not one in which its parts are immortal, but disposable.
In a network partition, no one can hear you scream
The first step to recover our system from a component's death is noticing that it happened at all.
Obviously, the dead component won't tell others that it's dead. It may be able to do so in a controlled scenario: a restart, a planned disconnection for maintenance, or something like that. But computers going off can also happen by accident, so we might as well assume that we won't hear about a computer dying from the computer itself.
This implies that we have to observe the death of a computer from the outside, somehow.
We also don't have an omniscient monitor that can observe the system from the outside. As we know, computers in a distributed system communicate through an unreliable network. This network is also the only way we've got to observe the health of a computer from the outside.
This implies that the operation to observe that a computer has died is distributed, and, thus, unreliable.
Dead â‰ˆ not alive
Since a dead computer can't tell us it's dead, we need to infer its death from a lack of its opposite: we try to get proof that it's alive. If we fail to do so, then it looks dead to us.
Death looks like a network partition
We say it "looks dead", and not "is dead", because the computer may be alive, but we can't communicate with it!
When we cannot communicate with a computer that is still alive, we're under a network partition. In effect, what used to be one network is now two, or more. (Under this definition, a network may just comprise a single computer.)
Both when a computer dies and when it's on the other side of a partitioned network, to us, it looks like the computer disappears.
Network partitions are tricky, because a part of the system thinking that a computer is dead when it isn't, and other parts of the system don't think the same, can have bad consequences.
High availability = no single point of failure
The buzzword that you want to include in your CV is that you know how to build highly available systems.
A system being available at some given time means that the services it is supposed to be offering can be offered. Availability is higher as more frequent those times are.
A truly highly available system continues operating correctly under network partitions. The service it provides may get degraded somehow, but it still serves its purpose.
This is usually a spectrum: we rarely can make systems totally partition-tolerant. Under a total network partition, we give up communication, and some tasks just cannot be performed without communicating with other computers.
At the very least, we can ensure that we have no single point of failure. If any individual component or operation that fails makes your system unavailable, it means that you have a single point of failure.
Detecting failure
The mechanisms we use to decide that a computer has disappeared, or, in other words, that it is unavailable, are called failure detectors.
Timeouts
We should be very familiar for now with the most basic of failure detectors: the timeout. If, after enough time has passed, some message you're expecting from a computer hasn't arrived, then you decide it is unavailable.
This may be combined with a number of failed retries, to try to account for delayed or lost individual messages.
Heartbeats
We've studied the concept of connections on top of unreliable networks. By keeping track of the order of each other's messages, they can detect out-of-order, duplicate and missing messages and pretend they're talking over a reliable medium.
But what if one of the computers loses track of such order, for example by dying? Then the connection is at least partially broken.
This will eventually be detected by a timeout when we want to send a new message to it and we don't get a delivery confirmation in time. Or maybe we get a connection failure response, such as a TCP RST message, instead of a confirmation.
The problem with that approach is that we don't detect a failure until we actually want to use the connection. If we had detected the failure before, we could have reacted to it sooner, when the connection was not in active use, and maybe the service wouldn't have been as degraded.
Also, in the meantime, maybe the other end has been trying to send us messages too, and, through a similar timeout detector, decided the connection was broken. All that time, the other end and you would be in disagreement about the health of the connection, so you wouldn't try to recover a working connection and you would be missing attempts to communicate with you until then.
Think about a chat application: it would be a terrible experience if it seemed that you were connected and people could talk to you until you decided to talk to someone, only to notice the connection failing at that point. You could spend hours thinking nobody is talking to you, when maybe that's not the case.
A solution to this is to periodically confirm with the other end that the connection is still in place, by sending messages and expecting confirmations with the sole purpose of reaffirming your belief. Those messages are called heartbeats.
If, after a stipulated time, you haven't received confirmations of such messages, or, on the other side, you haven't received any such messages, you immediately deem the connection broken.
Health checks
This is similar to heartbeats. While heartbeats usually are about connections, health checks usually involve a whole machine.
It works like this: a machine exposes an endpoint which others can request just for checking whether the machine is available, as opposed to actually performing an operation. Some monitor in another machine periodically calls this endpoint to get such confirmation. If this fails, then the machine is deemed unavailable.
What should the health check request handler do? It depends. If you do too much, you make the checks more expensive, maybe even affecting your actual service, and less resilient to accidental failures, such as transient networking errors, that don't really make you unavailable. If you do too little, you may be reporting yourself as available when in reality you can't do anything useful.
Health checks are often performed by reverse proxies to know the available backends they can route requests to, as we'll see in the next section.
What then? Failover
Once we've decided a computer is unavailable, what can we do about it?
Since we can't direct requests to it anymore, what we can do is to send requests to another, similar computer instead. This process is called a failover.
Redundancy
Many processes in our system will be almost stateless. The data they hold is either short-lived, such as open connections, requests in flight, or can be computed or retrieved from some other process, usually a database.
When this is the case, we can just have several instances of the same program running, and distribute requests to the service they provide among them. If any of them dies, then we stop directing requests at it, and direct them to any of the other instances instead.
This is usually achieved through a reverse proxy, such as HAProxy, Nginx, or Envoy.
It's a good idea to keep our programs stateless, and put data in systems that are designed specifically to store data: databases. Then, any number of stateless programs can connect to a single database.
Shadow followers
If we've got a good reason to make our program stateful, then we can't just route any given request to any random backend. Following some sharding criteria, we must direct requests to specific backends. We can assign a backend to a request based on session ID, user ID, source IP, or a similar token that spans several requests. Then, all the data associated with that token will be in its consistently assigned backend.
Even for stateless services that randomly assign requests to backends, proxies do this at the connection level: messages inside a TCP connection will be sent to the backend that holds the connection open, In this case, the sharding token is the source and destination port of the connection.
So what happens if the backend assigned to some token disappears? We can't just randomly reroute its requests to another backend, since the data associated with the token won't be there.
What we can do is to keep shadow followers: instead of a single backend for a token, we assign:

A leader backend, that processes the requests in full.
Some number of shadow followers that are notified somehow of the state changes of the leader, so that they can keep the same data in them.

In the case of failover, one of its shadow replicas are promoted to leadership. Since it has the same state as the previous leader, it can take over requests that were directed to it, almost as if nothing happened.
This is essentially what database replicas do, and, as we've seen, is pretty hard to do right, so it's better to leave this work to them if possible.
Shadow followers = stateful proxies
A problem with this approach is that the proxy needs to keep state: it needs to know which backend, both leader and followers, it has assigned to each token.
So we've moved the problem one layer up: what if the proxy disappears? We can't have only a single proxy directing traffic, since that would become a single point of failure.
As you can guess, we need to set up several proxies, and direct traffic from all of those to the right backend, for each request.
But we can't really follow the leader-followers approach here and assign specific proxies to requests, because who appoints the leader? Another proxy? Then it would be proxies all the way down!
This outer-layer distribution of traffic ultimately happens through DNS:

sequenceDiagram
  participant client1
  participant proxy1
  participant DNS
  participant proxy2
  participant client2
  client1 ->> DNS: get addresses for someservice.com
  DNS ->> client1: 1.2.3.4, 5.6.7.8
  client2 ->> DNS: get addresses for someservice.com
  DNS ->> client2: 1.2.3.4, 5.6.7.8
  Note left of client1: OK, I'll choose 1.2.3.4 (proxy1)
  Note right of client2: OK, I'll choose 5.6.7.8 (proxy2)
  client1 ->> proxy1: request
  client2 ->> proxy2: request


But, in this case, there's no leader: DNS distributes requests randomly among proxies. If we do nothing else, we end up in a situation in which each proxy assigns requests with the same sharding token to a different backend.
This is a kind of split-brain scenario. Keep reading!
Split-brain
Sometimes, there must be one, and only one, computer making decisions about something. Otherwise, they may contradict each other.
This is at odds with high availability: clearly, we cannot have just one computer assigned to some task. What if it disappears? Another computer must take over.
But we must still uphold the guarantee that only one computer at a time is doing the task. Otherwise, we end up in a situation called split-brain: the system has several decision-makers contradicting each other! We must avoid this, but how?
Leadership election
Appoint a leader through a consensus protocol, usually through something like ZooKeeper, etcd or Consul.
A database with serializable transactions or atomic compare-and-swap support, or a distributed lock, or even quorum reads in a leaderless database, might be good enough, though.
Don't outlive your leadership
When you're a leader, you must be really sure that you're still the leader before making sensitive decisions.
Just because you're alive and you were appointed leader in the past doesn't mean that you still are.
The sad part is, this is mostly impossible to do. Between the moment we confirm that we're still leader and we actually do what leaders do, an indeterminate amount of time may have passed, even if you do it right after checking, and others may have dismissed you from leadership.
To really avoid split-brain, in the general case, we must let go of high availability: decisions need to go through a single point of failure of some kind. But it's very rare that we need these extreme amounts of consistency. We probably can live with some level of split-brain risk.

003-backends-in-the-wild/02-deploying.ht.title: Deploying
003-backends-in-the-wild/02-deploying.ht.body:
Deploying
When programs fly the nest
The time comes for your little backend to go out there and serve a real service.
As you probably can imagine, running a distributed system in production is quite different from running it on your machine.
The basics are the same: programs running on computers on some Unix-like operating system (Linux, unless you have a picky sysadmin or very specific needs), connected to the Internet. However, the operational requirements wildly vary.
Let's see everything we want our production infrastructure to provide, and how to get there.
12-factor apps
First of all, your code needs to be adaptable to the environment. While developing, maybe you've been hardcoding URLs and file paths. Maybe you've been listening to whatever port directly. That's not going to fly now.
12-factor is a common set of conventions for designing programs to run in modern infrastructure. As with any set of good practices, it's a guideline rather than holy scripture.
The Web page is actually well-written and should be approachable to newcomers. Go and take a good look before continuing. As always, ask your mentor for help!
Versions coexisting for a while
When you deploy a new version of a service, the new version will coexist with the old one for some time.
Graceful deploys
To keep service disruption to a minimum, a deploy happens in stages:

A new process is started with the new version of the code.
We wait for the service to report itself as available, often through health checks.
We start routing new requests to the new process.
We stop routing new requests to the old process.
We wait for ongoing requests to the old process to finish by themselves for some time, and then start closing them in a gradual, controlled manner (graceful shutdown).
The old process stops, or is forcibly stopped.
Repeat for all instances we want to replace with the new version.

If we don't follow this exact order, there will be intervals in which requests will arrive to unavailable services.
Clients won't use the new API (yet)
So requests from clients will, for a small interval of time, arrive at both the old version and the new version of the code.
Even when only the new version is left running, clients will still be consuming the same API, so the new version must support it. As we've seen, your changes must be backwards-compatible.
The full deprecation path
Say we have version A in production, both in clients and servers, and we want to replace it with version B.

Deploy a new version of the server that serves both APIs A and B.
Release a new version of the client that only consumes API B.
Wait until no clients of A are left, or until you're satisfied you can break all old clients left. (This might take years or even never happen.)
Release a new version of the server that only serves API B.

Data migrations
APIs aren't the only thing that changes. The code handling saving and retrieving data from a database changes too, in a similar manner.
When you deploy a new version of your service, the stored data won't magically change at the same time to adapt to your new code. Instead, your new code must be compatible with existing data.
Making breaking changes will involve an intermediate stage in which you retrieve data in both the old and new versions, whatever exists, and store it in the new version. Eventually, no data still on the old version will exist, and you'll be able to delete code that handles it.
Staging environments
Before facing the public, you probably want to put your backend in an environment that resembles production as much as possible, but doesn't actually affect production. This will give you some extra confidence that your code will actually work.
Such an environment is usually called staging or preproduction (different people mean different things with those terms).
Load testing
A production-like environment is also a good place to check what happens when load increases.
You can change load factors (requests per second here and there, request size, entropy (how similar requests are to each other, for a relevant definition of similar), etc.) and also resource allocations independently or in coordination to see how different configurations affect the different parts of your system.
Testing in production
Whether you like or not, ultimately your changes will be tested in production.
The production environment can display some combination of factors that your testing pipeline hasn't anticipated that causes your changes to break.
Since this is always a possibility, you need to plan for it and try to reduce service impact in such scenarios. And, since you have to support this anyway, you can actually take advantage from it and not fret that much over your testing pipeline.
Sending a canary down the coal mine
A canary release is a first, limited, especially monitored release of your changes so that they only handle a small portion of the incoming requests.
This usually means just deploy a few, or even a single, instance of the new version, and let load balancers direct a proportional amount of traffic to it.
If you observe failures related to the canary, you kill the canary (if it's still alive) and, based on the data you've gathered from your monitoring, fix your changes and try again.
Otherwise, you gradually deploy to handle more and more of the requests, until the release is complete.
We will discuss at length how to observe such failures in future chapters.
Rolling back bad releases
Even if your changes passed the canary phase, an actual release that starts processes that handles more and more traffic, and replaces more and more of the old processes, can unleash failures due to the increasingly intense environment your changes live in.
When this happens, you need to be able to quickly deploy the previous version, to fall back to a (hopefully) stable state.
This process is called a rollback or a revert.
Assigning computing resources
Our programs happen to run in actual computers. Actual computers cost money, so ideally we want to assign computer resources to the different parts of your system optimally: enough to handle the amount of traffic you expect, but not much more than that.
Load testing and observing how production behaves can help you decide which are those optimal resources for each of your system components.
Schedulers
The art of assigning limited resources to processes with particular demands is called scheduling.
Systems such as Nomad and Kubernetes implement schedulers that take your requirements about the resources you need the and assign them to the available computing resources, automatically deploying then in the computers they decide.
Schedulers are often in charge also of monitoring the health of each process, so that a process that dies is automatically replaced.
No single computer, no single datacenter
Here are two facts of life:

A computer that dies takes down all processes running on it.
A datacenter that dies takes down all computers running on it.

Thankfully, the recipe for being robust in both scenarios is simple: don't put all your eggs in the same basket.
You should have some replicas or redundant instances of each of your backend services on different datacenters, and, within a datacenter, on different computers.
The problem is, communicating from one datacenter to another comes with big latencies, so you probably want to sacrifice some consistency there by only communicating the essential and doing so asynchronously when possible.
Finding others in a changing environment
So your scheduler will decide where it will actually run your processes. In fact, it will probably run them itself, taking charge of starting and stopping them, passing configuration to them, etc. It needs to decide which resources to allocate for a process, so it makes sense that it also takes care of actually running the process within its designated resources.
This means that you really can't predict which address any given process will have. How do you get processes to communicate? After all, you're trying to deploy a distributed system!
This problem is called service discovery, and it involves some number of registries. For example:

Redundant backends offering the same service need to register with their reverse proxy/load balancer.
Reverse proxies for a service need to register in some service registry, so that requests to that service reach them.
The outermost layer needs to listen to traffic directed at the IP addresses listed in the public DNS records.

Adjusting scale
For a variety of reasons, traffic goes up and down. You should adjust available resources accordingly.
Observations from production and load testing will help you predict how resource requirements change as different traffic patterns change.
Auto-scaling
Cloud providers let you order and dispose of computing resources on-demand, and often do so automatically by monitoring your performance.
A note about deploying microservices
In previous chapters we talked about some of the advantages that a microservices architecture is supposed to provide. We didn't really discuss its drawbacks.
Well, here they are: as the number of heterogeneous moving parts increase, we need to do more of the stuff presented in this chapter. It's hard to avoid that operating tens or hundreds or microservices usually result in a complexity explosion and quickly becomes a challenge. There's not really enough tooling in place to handle all this easily, and it remains an unsolved problem.

003-backends-in-the-wild/03-memory-isnt-.title: Memory isn't infinite
003-backends-in-the-wild/03-memory-isnt-.body:
Memory isn't infinite
Work takes memory for some time
It shouldn't come as a surprise that doing computing work involves allocating memory resources to it for some time.
This simple fact is often ignored. This would be a reasonable course of action if memory and time were infinite resources. Alas, they aren't!
Gracefully managing overloaded servers is a crucial missing piece in our magnificent strategy for designing robust systems.
As often happens, libraries, frameworks and tools make it absurdly convoluted to get this right. So you need to take the techniques we're going to learn to heart, and conscientiously apply them whenever you see a chance worth of them.
The bottleneck path to unavailability
Consider a system like this:

graph LR
  a["0/âˆž serving, +0.1 s/req"] --> b["0/3 serving, 0 queued, +1 s/req"]


The component at the left just takes requests and passes them to its dependency on the right.
The dependency on the right takes 1 second to serve a request, but it can only serve 3 requests at a time: additional concurrent requests are queued. As ongoing requests finish, the oldest requests in the queue are served.
The backend on the left adds 0.1 seconds per request to whatever its dependency takes to respond.
It's easy to see that this setup will happily serve requests at 1.1 seconds per request, as long as we don't have more than three concurrent requests at any time.
Meanwhile, we say that the component at the left can handle any number of concurrent requests. This isn't realistic, but it doesn't matter: since every request must go through the dependency, the only thing that matters is whether this dependency is faster than you or not.
When a dependency of yours is less performant than you, it becomes a bottleneck: even if your part of the work is pretty fast, you're still slow, because a bottleneck is slow.
Bottlenecks at capacity â†’ queued requests
But what happens if we go over that limit?
Suppose that requests reach the bottleneck at t+0.3, t+0.4, t+0.6 and t+0.8.
The first three requests will be responded after 1 s each, at t+1.3, t+1.4 and t+1.6 respectively. But what about the fourth? The fourth won't be responded at t+1.8, but at t+2.3, taking 1.5 s instead of 1 s. How so?

When it arrives at 0.8 s, the bottleneck will have three already. The bottleneck can't start working on the request yet, since it's at capacity: it is added to the queue.
Only when the first requests is responded, at t+1.3, will the component start working on the fourth request.
That takes a second, so t+1.3 + 1 s = t+2.3.

Note that this bottleneck doesn't need to be in an external service. It can be a CPU-intensive task, a shared connection to a database, or anything else that takes longer than you.
Queued requests â†’ higher response latencies
As more requests are queued, the latency of new requests increase: since they're taken from the queue later, and started later, they're also responded later.
Note that it only takes a sustained rate of >3 req/s to cause the queue to keep growing and growing. Even 3.00001 req/s will cause the queue to grow. Latencies will grow proportionally.
Higher response latencies â†’ more timeouts
Eventually, latencies will grow so much that the end clients will start timing out, resulting in failed requests.
Canceling such requests helps, as those requests can be removed immediately from the queue, but then the bottleneck will successfully process only the maximum amount of requests per second that keeps the slowest requests just under the client's timeout period.
More timeouts â†’ more retries
As we've learned, if we really want an operation to succeed, after a timeout, we retry it.
But if we do this, we accumulate:

The rate of new requests per second.
The rate of retried requests per second.

Just by following this strategy, the requests rate that our system is subjected to quickly skyrockets! Since we're already at capacity, incoming requests just fail, so new requests, retries, retries of retries, retries of retries of retries, etc. just accumulate, and we receive more and more requests per second.
At this point, the system is fully unavailable: none or almost none of the requests arriving to it are successfully served. They all just time out.
More retries â†’ more queued requests
This vicious circle, of course, makes the requests queue grow at exponentially increasing speed.
Enough queued requests â†’ memory exhaustion
Eventually, we just won't have enough space for more queued requests. What happens then? It boils down to two options:

Incoming requests are dropped.
In-flight requests are dropped, probably by crashing the whole process (OOM, Out Of Memory: the operating system starts killing processes).

It doesn't matter much: eventually we arrive at the same situation.
The unbounded concurrency path to unavailability
OK, that's assuming there's some bottleneck that consumes requests at a slower pace than requests arrive to it. What if there isn't? What if handling a request takes 0.1 s, or even 0.0001 s, and there's no limit (for the sake of argument) to the amount of concurrent requests after which we enqueue requests?
Enough request handlers â†’ memory exhaustion
So imagine that:

Handling a request takes 2 KB of memory.
Handling a request takes 0.0001 s.
The machine has 24 GB of memory.

It takes 24 GB / 2 KB = 12000 concurrent requests to run out of memory.
To create enough concurrent request handlers to fill that memory, we need to make 12000 requests in under 0.0001 s, which is 120 Mreq/s. Which is big, but not infinite!
The point is that, no matter how fast a request is handled, how little memory it consumes, or how much memory a machine has, there's some number of concurrent requests that results in memory exhaustion, which results in requests dropped, and thus, unavailability.
Needless to say, continuously retrying all those requests won't make things better.
Increasing requests/second by async queuing â†’ queue exhaustion
A first approach to reduce the impact of bottlenecks is to put the bottleneck behind an async message queue.
Returning to our example above, and assuming that publishing to the message queue is, say, 0.2 s, we effectively serve each request at 0.3 s. The actual work will take just as above, even more taking into account the message enqueueing and dequeuing overhead, but there won't be clients waiting for it, timing out, retrying, and making things worse.
This is useful if the request rate goes over our hard limit of 3 req/s for some time, then wears off and goes under it: the queue will fill for that interval, but then slowly decreases as the bottleneck catches up. Thus, queuing work is useful to resist temporary load spikes.
But if the request rate is constantly above our hard limit of 3 req/s, then the queue will eventually be exhausted too, and the message broker will be forced to reject new publishes, resulting again in unavailability, retries piling up, etc.
Backpressure
In face of all this, the rule for letting an overloaded system recover is rather simple:

Make fewer requests to an unavailable system, not more.

Forcibly reducing the requests per second that reach a system lets its bottleneck catch up with pending work, emptying queues. We then give the system operators the chance of making the bottleneck faster by scaling, or maybe just let the bottleneck solve itself if it was due to some temporary condition.
Designing clients for reducing load on unavailable services is called backpressure.
Implementing backpressure is probably the most ignored robustness mechanism out there, but it's absolutely crucial and not even hard to do.
Exponential backoff
We've repeated again and again that retrying is good, but we've seen it backfire badly when systems are overloaded. Should we give retries up then?
Not necessarily. We've left open the question of when we should retry an operation. Should we wait some time? How much?
Say we choose to retry a failed operation after 5 seconds. If we're consistently overloaded by the incoming request rate, that still means that retries will keep piling up, and the overall request rate, aggregating new requests, retries, retries of retries, etc. will still grow. Retrying each 30 seconds instead just makes this growth slower.
The solution is beautiful in its mathematical elegance: cancel out this tendency to grow by retrying any given operation less often over time.
As a result, retries will arrive evenly distributed in time. As the period of unavailability grows, retries don't pile up; instead, they will arrive over a proportionally growing period of time, but at a fixed rate.
This breaks the vicious circle and gives the system a chance to catch up with the new request rate requirements so that eventually the system is reliably available again.
Circuit breaker
An even more radical and effective way of reducing load to an unavailable system is to prevent all operations for some time on a service when one operation, or a few operations in a row, fails. During that period, way say that the circuit is broken.
While exponential backoff of retries of individual operations keeps the request rate to the unavailable service constant, circuit breakers reduce the request rate dramatically, to almost zero. This makes it so much easier for bottlenecks to recover quickly.
So, for how long should we keep the circuit broken? If we choose a big interval, we can often be pessimistically preventing operations while the service is actually available again. But if we choose a small interval, we make more requests to a service that may still be unavailable.
Choosing small interval is probably good enough: in practice, no system will get overloaded by receiving, say, 3 requests per second, which gives an interval of 0.3 s.
We can combine both approaches by implementing some exponential back off. But we must be careful to cap it at some reasonable interval, say 3-5 seconds. Otherwise, we might spend really long periods of time preventing requests that is back to normal.
Health as a spectrum
Another way of implementing backpressure is making health checks more nuanced: instead if responding "yes, I'm available" or "nope, I can't serve", respond with some measurement of the level of overload in the server. (A high percentile of the latencies over a period is a good metric.)
The load balancer can then forward fewer requests to slower backends, making it easier on them to recover.
Of course, this only helps when the overload is asymmetric. It won't help if, as it's often the case, all backends of a service are equally overloaded since they depend on the same bottleneck.
In the end, the bottleneck must be fixed
Backpressure is great for avoiding making the problem worse, but, by itself, won't make the problem disappear: we're receiving more requests that our system supports.
This points to an insufficient resource allocation. If it's due to some transient failure somewhere, the resources may come back by themselves, but if we are just getting more traffic that we've designed for, then we must scale up the system.

003-backends-in-the-wild/06-observabilit.title: Observability
003-backends-in-the-wild/06-observabilit.body:
Observability
Why we need to observe
As we've seen, our services and our infrastructure are more distributed and ephemeral day by day. Our systems are more advanced and every one have different reliability targets, requirements and guarantees. All the cloud services (and custom services if configured properly) provides a robust abstraction over network and hardware failures, which means that as software developers we must ensure that our applications are good enough to survive with that networking and scheduling abstractions. We need to gain visibility into the behavior of our applications.
Traditionally the systems engineers had some dashboards with operational monitoring and alerting (CPU/Memory/...), and that was enough to know if the application was going well or no. Nowadays with distributed systems we need to go further in order to ensure the correct behavior of our system. That's Observability, it's more than logs, metrics and traces. In the most abstract and complete way, observability is a property of a system that has been designed, built, tested, deployed, operated, monitored, maintained and evolved in acknowledgment of this facts:

No complex system is ever fully healthy
Distributed Systems are pathologically unpredictable
It's impossible to predict the myriad states of partial failure the parts of the system might end up
Failure needs to be embraced in every phase: system design, implementation, testing, deploying and operation
Ease of debugging is a cornerstone for the maintenance and evolution of robust systems

Monitoring and Observability
Observability is not a substitute to monitoring, observability is a superset of monitoring, which means that to achieve observability you will need good monitoring, but you will need more things.
We'll focus on some techniques of observability, but there are many more, observability it's more a team mindset than a set of tools or techniques. All the system has to be designed with some concepts in mind:

A system need to be prepared to be tested in a realistic manner.
A system can be deployed gradually and the roll-back/roll-forward are easy, fast and can be automatic
A system must be able to report data points about his health and behavior.

Monitoring
Monitoring is the way to report the overall health of the system and create alerts. The monitorized data can be very different, RAM/CPU used, requests/s, latency, DNS lookup, etc. The key factor of monitoring is that is predictable (you can assume that if some metric goes higher than X you have a problem), it affects the end users, and needs human intervention as soon as possible.
There are two general types of monitoring (You can learn more here):

Blackbox monitoring. You observe the systems from the outside, this is the most common monitoring done in the companies, and it refers to metrics like CPU, disk space, memory, load averages, etc.
Whitebox monitoring. You observe the applications running instead of the systems, with distributed systems is more common. It can be metrics like SQL queries running, number of users in an application, requests with error or requests with success, etc.

Even though whitebox monitoring is used more and more, we can't forget blackbox monitoring, specially when you depend of external services (like a database hosted by a third party company) that you can only do blackbox monitoring.
Alerting
Monitoring data must provide a global view of the health of a distributed system exposing high-level metrics over time across all components (load balancers, caches, databases, services). An alert must have some monitoring data attached with the ability to drill down into components and systems to diagnose the scopes and the nature of the fault.
Additionally, in the occurrence of an alert, the monitoring data should be able to provide visibility into the impart of the failure and the effect of any fix deployed. Also, for the best on-call experience, all alerts need to be actionable, which means that you have to be able to know what to do with the alert data.
There are two set of metrics for monitoring purposes:

USE methodology analyses the system performance. The metrics will be used for measuring utilization, saturation and errors or system resources, eg: memory, CPU, divide errors, queue length.
RED methodology analyses the applications. This method calls for monitoring the request rate, error rate and duration of request. Really necessary for monitoring request-driven applications.

Coding and testing in production
As we've seen, observability is a state of mind where the whole system has been developed with it in mind, and one important point in this is not rely only on pre-production testing. It's important, but being able to test in production elevates the resilience of your code and your observability. In order to achieve that state, the whole team will need to code and test for failure, instead of coding for success.
There are three main things to write code for failure:
Operational semantics of the application
The developer must be aware of the operational semantics of the application, for example:

How the service will be deployed
How an application handles signals
How it registers with service discovery
How it discovers upstreams
How graceful the restarts will be
How the configuration will be received
The concurrency model
...

There are many operational questions that nowadays the platform abstract from the developer, and it's important to be aware of all of them.
Operational characteristics of the dependencies
You need to know, not only your operational characteristics, but the ones of your dependencies, so you are able to know if you want to use the default values of the dependencies or override it with your own value.

How your cache library/service will work
The configuration of your database library, the connection pool size, timeouts, etc

Debuggable code
If your code is debuggable, you will be able to ask questions to your application when you are in trouble. For this you'll need to understand the instrumentation of choice (metrics, logs, exception traces, ...) and the pros/cons. With that knowledge, being able to pick the best combination of instrumentation for your service requirements. It seems an easy task, but it's not easy at all.
Testing for failure
Writing unit tests is important, but you will need to do more testing in order to improve your confidence in the application. At the end, unit testing only shows the happy path of your scope (and probably heavily mocked). But we know that when the complexity of the systems grows, it will fail in more complex ways that you can't predict.
Lately more and more ways of testing in production have appeared, and many of them will need you to write your application in order to ease that task.
Here are the phases of testing, as you can see there are a myriad of tests.

Testing in production is hard, and not eliminate all the system failures, but it will build confidence in the reliability of complex distributed systems
Logging
An event log is an immutable, timestamped record of events that happened over time. There are three main forms of event logs:

Plain-text, the most common format of logs, this is just free text

[2018-11-14T18:50:18.003Z]  INFO: hello/40026 on rock.local: hi ironhack

Structured, in recent days it's the beloved way to go, usually the format is JSON

{
    "time": "2018-11-14T18:50:18.003Z",
    "level": "info",
    "msg": "hi ironhack",
    "hostname": "rock.local",
    "name": "hello",
    "pid": 40026
}


Binary, instead of an structured text format, is an structured binary format, like Protobuf or MySQL's binlog.

The logs are important, because it's the application diary of all the activity, if the logs are detailed we can investigate when we have a bug or some error.
Log events are the easiest observability key point to generate, since they are just text or JSON that the application generates and emit, and most languages have logging frameworks and libraries. In the logs you can add all the metadata you want, which provides a highly granular information with rich local context. Even more, if you use structured logging and some processor like ELK (Elasticsearch, Logstash, Kibana) you will find much more data and relations in your event logs.
The main problem of logs is the performance, due to that most of the default or de-facto libraries are bad in performance. They are slow, write synchronously and/or have a big memory footprint. And, even with some really performant libraries, logging excessively has the capability to affect the application performance.
Event data can be used in more situations than debugging, it's a great source of analytics data. The same event logs processed by a server can answer some business questions like "Filter the countries from where users viewed this page less than 100 times", meanwhile for debugging the same data can answer questions like "Show page loads from Spain that took more than 10s to load". The usual way to be able to do this kind of queries is to treat your event data like any other streaming data, processed by some indexing stores like Elasticsearch.
Metrics
Metrics are a numeric representation of data measured over intervals of time. They bring the power of mathematical modeling and predictions to the current and future system's behaviors.
Unlike logging, metrics are mainly numeric representations, which are easily optimized for storage, processing and querying. This properties makes metrics perfectly suited to build dashboards with historical trends.
Classic metric tools only had the metric name, timestamp and the metric value, which is limiting when you want to graph interactions between different applications in your distributed system. Modern metric tools such as Prometheus or newer versions of Graphite apart of the three classic values provides a way to assign labels to the metric.
For example, the metrics for the duration of endpoints of an API, in an classic way would look like:
{
    "name": "get_estimation",
    "date": "2018-11-14T18:50:18.003Z",
    "value": "200"
}

Instead, if the metric tools have labels support, you can have a generic metric for request, and add the granularity with labels:
{
    "name": "request_duration",
    "date": "2018-11-14T18:50:18.003Z",
    "value": "200",
    "labels": {
        "method": "get",
        "action": "estimation",
        "environment": "production",
        "code": "200",
        "code_family": "2xx"
    }
}

The advantages of metrics over logs is that transfer and storage has constant overhead. Unlike logs, with user traffic won't incur a significant increase in disk utilization, processing complexity, operational cost. The storage increases with more permutations of labels values but the client-side aggregation doesn't increase proportionally with user traffic.
The are some metric tools, like statsd, that works in push model, which means that it sends the data to the server, which can lead to an auto DDOS to the metrics server. Other metric tools, like Prometheus, use the pull model, where the metrics server knows of the applications that it needs to "scrape" and every few seconds (that can be configured) retrieves the aggregated metrics from the applications. This pull based metric servers allow them to use back-pressure on the clients when they are not working properly.
Thanks to the mathematical benefits, and that running queries against time-series databases is better on metrics that in some indexing storage for logs, it makes the metrics the tool best suited to trigger alerts.
The main drawback of metrics is that they are system scoped, it's really hard to understand anything cross-application. With labels you can mitigate this, with the increase of metric storage of course. You could add some request UUID as label to all the metrics, so you can trace easily the metrics of that query in the distributed system, but this can overwhelm time-series databases, and it will make the graphs and queries slow. All popular time-series databases suffer performance under high cardinality labeling.
Logs and metrics are perfect for a single system, and it's enough to understand the performance and behaviour of individual systems, but they aren't sufficient to understand the lifetime of a request in a distributed systems, to achieve that we'll need one more technique.
Tracing
A trace is a representation of a causally related distributed events that encode end to end request flow through a distributed systems.
Traces are used to identify the amount of work done at each layer while preserving causality by using "happens-before" semantics.
When a request begins, it's assigned a globally unique ID, which is propagated throughout the request path so every point of instrumentation will be able to enrich the metadata before passing around the ID when doing other requests. When the execution flow reaches the instrumented point a record is emitted with the metadata. With all that events with the unique ID and the metadata, we are able to construct the flow of execution based of the different events emitted in different parts of the system.

Having an understanding of the entire request cycle makes it possible to debug requests spanning to multiple services to identify the source of the increased latency.
There are many use-case for distributed tracing, primarily used for inter service dependency analysis, distributed profiling and debugging.
The most popular OpenTracing compliant solutions are Jaeger and Zipkin.
As you can imagine, adding distributed tracing retroactively in an existing infrastructure is really hard, every component in the path needs to be modified to propagate the tracing information. You can start adding it, and you will have big gaps where the tracing has not been added, which can be better than not having tracing at all, but some people think that this blind spots makes debugging even harder.
The second problem is that it's not enough to instrument your code, you need to instrument the libraries and frameworks that you use, which can be really hard sometimes.
While tracing is difficult to implement, we've seen a rise in "service meshes", which makes almost effortless adding the tracing functionality. The service mesh most used by far is istio.

101-appendix-containers/.title: Containers
101-appendix-containers/.body:
Containers
We are going to take advantage of the container technology for this bootcamp, so we're going to explain briefly what they are and how to use them.
Modern operating systems allow to have multiple user-space instances, that look like real computers from the point of view of programs running in them. The difference between a program running in an ordinary operating system and a program running in a container is that the latter can only see a subset of the resources that are visible for the former, those assigned to the container.
For the bootcamp, we are mostly interested in the flexibility that containers offer. Since each container behaves as it's a different computer, we can simulate a complete distributed system locally, in our own computers.
Docker
Docker is one of the best known container system available and is the one we will use during the bootcamp.
A docker system is composed of a daemon (dockerd) and a client (docker). The client communicates with the daemon that listens for commands. We will always interact through the client.
Docker manages several different entities, we are interested in just two:

A docker image, a template used to build docker containers.
A docker container, which uses a docker image to build the actual isolated environment and run the applications.
A docker registry, which is a (local or remote) repository for docker images.

The usual workflow while working with docker is:

Create an image or get one from a docker registry
Run a container based on the image
Stop the container

Image creation
To create an image first we have to define it.
This is usually done in a Dockerfile file.
Here we can see an example of a simple node application image:
FROM node:latest
ADD . /app
WORKDIR /app
RUN npm install
CMD ["node", "index.js"]

Now we can build the image with:
$ docker build -t myapp:latest .

myapp is the name we tag the image with. This will be used to run a container based on this image.
You can see the available images with:
$ docker images

Run a container
You can run a container either using your own image as explained in the previous section, or some image available in some docker registry.
For example, the command to run a container based on the image built previously would be:
$ docker run myapp

To run a container publicly available in a docker registry (for example, a mongodb image):
$ docker run mongo

In this case, the docker command does two different things:

Download the image
Run the container built from this image

The first step can also be done separately with:
$ docker pull mongo

Docker compose
Docker provides an easy way to build, share and run containers, which is great.
But we are building distributed systems, and having to run each container manually becomes tedious fast.
There are several ways to approach such problem, we'll go with docker compose.
Docker compose is a tool to define an run multi-container applications and will allow us to build the systems we will use in the exercises locally quite easily.
To define such multi-container system, a configuration file, in YAML format, is used.
The configuration file for the first exercise is as follows:
version: '3'
services:
  exercise1:
    build: .
    ports:
     - "9001:9001"
  messageapp:
    image: "cabify/backend-bootcamp-messageapp:latest"
    ports:
      - "3000:3000"

The configuration file is composed of:

A configuration format version in the first line
Containers definition in the rest of the file. There are two services:
exercise1: A container that is built using the image described in Dockerfile in our current directory and will listen in port 9000.
messageapp: A container that is built using the image tagged with cabify/backend-bootcamp-messageapp:latest (which may be available either locally or in a docker registry), which will listen in port 3000.



This is just the basics of how to configure a multiple container system with docker compose, but it should give a quick overview of the idea. Check the references for more information.
Now, we just need to build the system we have just described:
$ docker-compose build

and run it:
$ docker-compose run

This will launch both services in containers as defined above.
References
We have only covered the basics of containers, docker and docker compose.
You can take a look to the following resources for further information:

Docker Get Started.
The firt 3 steps cover the same material seen here in more detail:
docker concepts and setup, buiding an example app with docker, and buiding a multi-container system with docker compose.
Docker documentation The official docker documentation site.
Awesome Linux Containers A big catalog with further resources.

102-appendix-good-practices/.title: Good Practices
102-appendix-good-practices/.body:
Good Practices
Software Engineering is more than just writing code[1]. By Software Engineer, we don't mean a person with a degree in Computer Science. But one who looks at writing quality software as their profession.  Knowing how to program is not enough to make software engineering. There are several analogies that help us to understand this:

Everyone can sing (especially in the shower), but if you have to throw a party you probably hire professional musicians.
Everyone can cook. But when itâ€™s time to feed a lot of people we hire a Chef.
Everyone can write, but it doesn't mean you are a novel author.

Software is not different. You might know how to program and you might be able to code simple programs, but that's different from writting engineered programs. And one thing that characterizes a engineered program is the code quality.
Code quality is subtle. There are some code constructions that could cause real troubles to the authors, and directly or indirectly also to the users. There are also some good practices that help to avoid such harmful constructions and improve the quality of our sofware. Along this appendix, we will describe some of them, divided in two different sections:

General good practices. Some general principles to write better sofware.
Design good practices. Good practices applied to the sofware design and software architecture.

Important disclaimer: this is about good practices. You should not interpret this as The Truth. It's a guide, a compendium of tricks and advices to make better software. Do not read it as a code of conduct. We expect you to apply your own criteria and think by yourself while coding.
[1]: https://edgecoders.com/software-engineering-is-different-from-programming-b108c135af26 Samer Buna - Software Engineering is Different from Programming

102-appendix-good-practices/01-general-p.title: General Good Practices

102-appendix-good-practices/02-design-pr.title: Design Good Practices
102-appendix-good-practices/02-design-pr.body:
Design Good Practices
At the beginning, every software project is a masterpiece. Everything is simple, clean, concise, elegant. But then the time passes, and the software start to rot. It's a progressive process: an ugly part here, a little hack there. And over time the rotting continues until our beautiful codebase becomes a mess that the developers find increasingly hard to maintain. Eventually, the effort required to make the simplest of changes to the software becomes so high that the engineers cry for a full rewrite (likely using microservices :-) ).
Symptoms of rotten software
But, how do we detect our codebase is rotting? There are four symptoms that could help to detect it.

Rigidity. The tendency of the software to be difficult to change. Every single change causes a cascade of changes in other parts of the code (dependencies). What seemed to be a two days change becomes several weeks of work. This derives in unhappy managers, who in degenerate cases reduce the changes to critical fixes only. The software stops adding new value to the business. And the product collapses.

Fragility. The tendency of the software to break upon changes. Very often, changes that have nothing to do with the part that brokes. Managers are afraid to make changes, so they limit them as they do before rigidity. Again, in degenerated cases we stop adding new value, and the product collapses.

Immobility. The inability to reuse software fragments. When one programmer detects he needs a module that is similar to one that other programmer wrote. However, the module to be reused is tangled with its dependencies, and the cost of separating things is too great. And the module is simply rewritten.

Viscosity. The tendency of the software to make it difficult to preserve the design, stimulating the programmer to make hacks instead. In other words, it's easy to do the wrong thing, but hard to do the right thing. This is something that applies not only to the code but also to the development environment: build systems, testing frameworks, service configuration, etc.


Causes of rotten software
There is one simple root cause for our beloved software to degrade: changing requirements. That's essentially why our codebase starts as a clean, elegant solution. Not only because it is small, but also because we start defining our architecture based on clear requirements. So we make a design that does the job really well. But, the sooner or later the requirements will change. And the software will have to give response to things it was not designed for.
We cannot expect the requirements not to change. This is a essential part of software development. What we have to do is to find a way to make our designs resilient to changes. But, what kind of changes could degrade our designs so much? Simple: those that introduce new and unplanned dependencies. Each of the four symptoms described above is either directly or indirectly caused by improper dependencies between the modules of our software. We have to manage the dependencies to prevent they propagate. We need dependency firewalls.
SOLID Principles
There are five well-known principles in Object Oriented Programming (but most of them applicable to other programming paradigms) that could be followed in order to manage module dependencies. We will analyze them in detail in the reminder of this appendix.
S: Single Responsibility Principle (SRP)
Each software module should have one and only one reason to change.
This is another formulation of the principles of cohesion and coupling: gather together the things that change for the same reasons. Separate those things that change for different reasons. That's exactly the meaning of one reason to change. If there are more than one business logic coded in a module, we will have more than one single person (or business unit) requesting changes in that module. As consequence, the changes requested by one person could impact the business logic under the responsibility of another one: introducing new bugs, changing the behavior unexpectedly, affecting the performance, etc.
Let's see an example. Consider a module that generates and prints a finantial report. If we think about it, we could distinguish two different reasons to change, as:

Change what are the contents of the report. We might want to add a new item that tells how much we invested in floppy disks in the last month.
Change how this report is printed. We might want to generate a PDF output instead of the HTML one we had so far.

The SRP says that these two aspects of the problem are really two separate responsibilities, and should therefore be in separate modules.
O: Open Closed Principle (OCP)
A module should be open for extension but closed for modification.
It means simply this: we should write our modules so that they can be extended, without requiring them to be modified. In other words, we want to be able to change what the modules do, without changing the source code of the modules.
An essential way to achieve this is creating abstractions. In Object Oriented Programming, we can define abstract classes or interfaces that define the contract of the module. The code that depends in such module will depend in these abstract classes or interfaces, and not in the implementations. If we need to extend the module, it's as simple as adding new classes that implements the abstract class or interface to the module. That requires no change in any existing code. Neither in our module, neither in others that depends on it.

If you are not familiar with terms like interace of abstract class, you can read this introduction to polymorphism and abstract types.

Let's see this with an example. Let's assume we have a web application that have to authenticate an HTTP request to ensure it contains a valid username and password. We put all the code that does the authentication in a function authorize(user, password) that, given a user and a password, indicates whether that user is authenticated. Internally, this funcion queries the DB to look for that user and check if the password matches.
This design is not following OCP. If we want to add a new way to authenticate users (e.g., LDAP, OAuth, etc), we will have to change most of the code in the authorize function. A nice way to follow OCP would be to define a AuthenticationProvider abstract class.

graph TD
  AP["Â«interfaceÂ»AuthenticationProvider----------------------------------+ authorize(user, password)"]

  RequestHandler --> AP
  AP-. implements .-DbAuthenticationProvider
  AP-. implements .-LdapAuthenticationProvider
  AP-. implements .-OauthAuthenticationProvider
  AP-. implements .-More[...]

  style LdapAuthenticationProvider fill:#afa;
  style OauthAuthenticationProvider fill:#afa;
  style More fill:#afa;


This provides an abstract method authorize(user, password).  Our request handlers would have access to an instance of AuthenticationProvider, so they only have to invoke authorize and forget about the details of how it is implemented. Initially, we would provide a DbAuthenticationProvider class that implements the interface defined by AuthenticationProvider. If we want to add more authentication methods, we would add new classes to the design: LdapAuthenticationProvider, OAuthAuthenticationProvider, etc, without changing a single line of code in auth module.
L: Liskov Substitution Principle (LSP)
Subclasses should be substitutable for their base classes.
The concept is simple. Derived classes should be substitutable for their base classes. That is, a user of a base class should continue to
function properly if a derivative of that base class is passed to it. This may seem obvious, but there are subtleties that need to be considered. The canonical example is the Circle/Ellipse dilemma.
Most of us learn, in high school math, that a circle is just a degenerate form of an ellipse. All circles are ellipses with coincident foci. So we can have a definition of ellipse as:
class Ellipse {
  constructor(focusA, focusB, radius) {
    this.focusA = focusA;
    this.focusB = focusB;
    this.radius = radius;
  }

  get focusA() { return this.focusA; }
  get focusB() { return this.focusB; }
  get radius() { return this.radius; }

  set focusA(val) { this.focusA = val; }
  set focusB(val) { this.focusB = val; }
  set radius(val) { this.radius = val; }

  area() {
    return ...;
  }
}

A ellipse is a pair of foci points and a radius. We provide some getters and setters, and a method to calculat its area from the properties. Now, we can define the circle as:
